title: The Bit In Between
author: Varley, Claire
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've received this novel through Netgalley, many thanks to Pan Macmillan Australia for the opportunity to read and .This novel was wonderfully rI've received this novel through Netgalley, many thanks to Pan Macmillan Australia for the opportunity to read and .This novel was wonderfully refreshing, quirky, albeit, at times a bit slow.The first chapter is fantastic and it stars off beautifully: "This is how it starts. A young man sits alone in an airport lounge. The seat beside him is empty. Someone sits down. This is how it starts and every time it starts like this. In every universe. In every dimension. In every possible version of this story, this is the start. It starts like this because life is nothing but a series of tides and waves, the constant movement of a vast ocean propelled by the sun, the moon and what scientists swear to us isn't magic. Most times they trickle, sometimes they surge, and every so often the earth realigns and the ocean responds in kind."I was captivated. The first few pages are beautiful. "There are no tsunamis in this story - no seismic vibrations or geological cataclysms - but there are waves". This phrase describes this novel perfectly, as it's not about any major dramatic twists in the main characters' lives, but it's about life and its occasional waves. The Bit in Between is the story of Oliver and Alison, both in their mid twenties, both going through some sort of life crisis. Oliver is an anxious writer, whereas Alison is impulsive and doesn't really know who she is or what she wants.Their first encounter is very amusing, albeit, not for poor Oliver. Their accidental meeting in an airport lounge turns into a relationship. So Alison ends up following Oliver to the Solomon islands, where he is going to write his second novel.Life in the Solomons is slow; Oliver is trying to write and for weeks he doesn't come up with anything worth keeping. Meanwhile, Alison just wonders around, exploring the area, shopping for food. Little by little, she immerses herself into the local culture, thanks mostly to her new local friend, Sera. Meanwhile, Oliver makes friends with an American expat, Rick. Life drags on, Oliver and Alison start having little squabbles here and there. Oliver seems to have found inspiration, which is mostly drawn from Alison and his life in the Solomons. Oliver has a feeling that Alison is going to leave him. Will she? Claire Varley's debut novel is very well written, funny at times and insightful. I loved that Ms Varley's painting of the Solomons is done without prejudice and at the same time there's no painting over with bright colours where there shouldn't be any. The character development is expertly done. Both protagonists are incredibly realistic, their struggles felt authentic, and many will probably identify. Even the title is extremely well chosen.Why I'm not giving this 5-stars? It's because I was kind of puzzled by these back stories for many of the transient and inconsequential characters: a cab driver, an aunt, a lady in a cafe etc. I really couldn't see the point. The only thing I could come up with was that the author wanted to show that everybody has a story, which is true, but still, I thought they were distracting and a bit annoying, especially once I'd realised I was never going to come across those characters again. Regardless, this is an impressive first novel, from a very talented writer. Looking forward to reading the next novel from Claire Varley.Recommended: To readers who enjoy realistic, finding yourself stories.Cover: 5 stars...more

title: Ricochet        (Vigilantes, #1)
author: Lake, Keri*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This novel was quite an unexpected surprise. I sort of 1-clicked it by accident, and since the book I was reading was not appealing and a bit tedious,This novel was quite an unexpected surprise. I sort of 1-clicked it by accident, and since the book I was reading was not appealing and a bit tedious, I decided to give this one a try, thinking it would be a romance novel. I was intrigued from the very first page, but then, on the second page, I came across this:"Outside the window, broken and abandoned husks dotted the landscape, set against the gray, dishwater sky. Scarred and beaten, the perfect metaphor for the people who lived within its forgotten neighborhoods, Detroit was like an abused kid, just waiting for the day someone would come along and give a fuck about it. The third world city of America." I had to go to back the beginning to check what book I was reading because, really, that was one beautiful, evocative paragraph. I am trying to do this book justice. There are plenty of aspects of this novel that are somewhat cliche: it's got the damaged, muscly, hunky, tattooed guy. His name is Nick. The main heroine is Aubree Cullin and she's, of course, hot and damaged. And you've got the expected sexual tension/conflict between the two, before the hot sex scenes ensue. And there's a lot of sex scenes, many were quite gritty, and I thought, at times, a bit over-the-top, but that's a matter of taste, I'm sure many will find them very hot.Another character in this novel is Alec Vaughn/Achilleus X, master hacker, an hacktivist. Nick and Alec have been conspiring for three years to bring down Michael Culling and his wife, Aubree, for having ordered Nick's wife and son killing. Nick ends up kidnapping Aubree. They fall for each other. Will they end up together? Will Nick get his revenge? This novel is dark. There's abuse, torture, extreme violence, rape, bad language etc. We're dealing with the most depraved and heartless. Even the main hero is very dark.I'm not going to say that this novel was perfect, as there were a few things that bugged me:- the young age of the protagonists: Nick is 28 and Aubree is 24. I found that disconcerting because that would have meant that Nick got married/had a child when he was 19-20 years old, and Aubree got married at 19? Speaking of ages, Aubree's husband was in his 30's but (view spoiler)[ he was a childhood friend of Aubree's, so they would have been closer in age, so it didn't make sense that he was so much older - just saying (hide spoiler)]. In my opinion, it would have been more credible if Nick was in his early thirties and Aubree in her late twenties. Also, for someone who didn't finish high school, Nick sounded very articulate. Regardless, this novel is not bad, I didn't even mind the first person narrative, with alternate POVs and lots of flashbacks, because they were well done. Honestly, this was unexpectedly well written and gripping and it kept my interest to the end. There were a few unexpected twists and turns that I didn't see coming so I enjoyed that very much. It's such a shame that Keri Lake doesn't write novels that'd be more up my alley, as I really don't care for paranormal, fantasy, shape-shifters, warevolves etc. Here's hoping that this novel will be followed by others that can be labelled as contemporary/women's fiction....more

title: King        (King, #1)
author: Frazier, T.M.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Oh dear... I should really start paying more attention to the blurbs and to the 1-2 star s.This novel is full of inconsistencies, with characterOh dear... I should really start paying more attention to the blurbs and to the 1-2 star s.This novel is full of inconsistencies, with characters who seem to have multiple personalities.Here's another novel where the heroine, Jane Doe, has total amnesia. Total amnesia doesn't really happen and if it does, it doesn't last for too long unless there was major brain trauma, which would leave someone physically/mentally incapacitated. But I was willing to let that go, for the sake of being entertained. There's a lot of swearing in this novel, but it didn't bother me. But plot holes do bother me, so do inconsistencies and unrealistic scenarios. And this novel abounds in all of them. I didn't think much of King, our main hero, although, like most xx chromosome beings, I was looking for redeemable, likeable characteristics. True, I do not like bad guys, and I can't stand tattoos, so even his physical appearance wasn't that enticing to me. But no problem there, I'm more interested in character development. I really am! :-) The fact that he's attracted to someone who was emaciated and looked underage just speaks volumes of what a creep he was. And the way he was talking to and about women, that didn't agree with me. And I thought it was ironic since he was the father of a little girl, whom he claimed to love.The author threw in some titbits that were supposed to make us like and understand him: bad upbringing, his willingness to get his daughter back no matter what; he's even got a bachelor's degree; apparently he's a great friend and few other bits and pieces. So all those things should really make us like him, no matter that he left his mum burn to death, no matter that he killed people, not to mention the drugs and the guns. But hey, he was a hunk, so that makes everything OK. Right? As for the main heroine, Doe, she's amnesiac, and full of contradictions. She left the foster house because of perverts, but then she's willing to sleep with bikers for food and shelter. Yeah, that makes sense.There were too many things that didn't add up and a couple of really strange scenes that didn't make sense and were unresolved.The editing, if there was any, was subpar. For instance conscious and consciousness are not the same thing. "... I could get back to the thing that used to be important to me without this lingering sense of dread looming in my conscious". Conscious is an adjective, not a noun. Fortunately, this wasn't the worst book I've read when it comes to grammar mistakes and typos. With better editing, this novel could have been better. But as it stands, it's only a 2-star read for me....more

title: A Little Life
author: Yanagihara, Hanya*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I thought I would feel more benevolent towards 'A Little Life' after some time had passed. But no! As I was telling a friend, I'm still gobsmacked by I thought I would feel more benevolent towards 'A Little Life' after some time had passed. But no! As I was telling a friend, I'm still gobsmacked by how little I was touched by it all. This novel had all the elements that normally kill me, but I only shed a few tears once while at the same time being annoyed/angry with the author. (view spoiler)[I usually cry buckets, but despite all the horrible things that happened to Jude, I only cried a bit when Willem died, while at the same time thinking "you have got to be fucking kidding" Another huge tragedy?! It may sound bad, well, it is bad, but I was relieved when Jude killed himself. Relieved! Because the book is ending!!! This is tragedy/misery porn, made worse by the fact that it's disguised by the medium of literary fiction. (hide spoiler)]NB: This is the Sarahcl's extended  on her blog. She articulates things much better than I ever could: https://iamreadingthereforeiam.wordpr... _____________________________I've just finished reading this novel. I don't want to dwell on it for too long, I want to move on quickly, preferably onto something light, fluffy and optimistic as this was, as you all well know, depressing.Right, where do I start?I had very high expectations from A Little Life, given the praises of so many here on GR and in the literary world. Many called it "the book of the year", some even said "the book of the decade". So, I thought it must be an astounding piece of literature.I wasn't impressed. I'll try to articulate it here, mostly trying to make sense to myself, why it didn't work for me. Advanced apologies for the blabbering.  Spoiler Alert: the  contains spoilers. The beginning:"The Eleventh apartment had only one closet, but it did have a sliding glass door that opened onto a small balcony, from which he could see a man sitting across the way, outdoors in only a T-shirt and shorts even though it was October, smoking. Willem held up a hand in greeting to him, but the man didn't wave back."I had to re-read this to make sure I didn't skip any words. That didn't make for a favourable first impression, but I thought, don't be hasty, there are 700+ pages to come. So I continued, anticipating enlightenment, passion, awe and literary mastery.Well, I struggled with the first 20%+, as the characters' introduction was tedious, and it took me a while to get used to the names and who was who. As I progressed, it got marginally better and better. But it was still in the realm of "it's OK, but something's missing; where's the literary masterpiece"?The novel is about four men, who become close friends in college: Willem, JB, Malcolm and Jude. Relatively early on we realise that Jude St Francis is the sun and his friends are like planets who orbit around him, some closer than others. Slowly, we learn a little more about Jude. Everybody loves Jude, but I struggled understanding why they cared so much. Men, especially young men, (I apologise for the generalisation), mostly care about sex and power. Given that there was no sex involved and that Jude was not particularly useful to anyone - the blind devotion and friendship didn't quite make sense. Especially, when there was no meeting of souls, there were no shared confidences, as Jude's completely secretive about his past. Yet, his friends just let him keep quiet, never ask him any questions? Incredulous! Another aspect that puzzled/irritated me was Jude's reluctance to take pain medication, in spite of his "episodes" that left him incapacitated and very embarrassed. Then, there is Andy, an orthopaedic surgeon, who becomes his doctor, practically at his beck and call. That was one of the most unrealistic relationships. Andy had a family of his own, yet he seemed to barely sleep, always trying to help Jude, always concerned about him, always treating him for a multitude of ailments. I thought to myself, surely, he must be in love with Jude. But no, he was just being a good doctor and friend. I'm no expert, but I know doctors have strict rules and regulations, where they need to report certain things.And poor Jude just doesn’t get a break. He’s surrounded by wonderful people, all very giving, all caring for him. Yet he still can’t talk about what had happened to him. I can (try to) understand why he wouldn't tell his closest friends or his wonderful adoptive parents about his past, but not speaking with a psychologist/psychiatrist, not doing anything to try to get better was too fatalist, too selfish, I thought quite incomprehensible. For somebody who was supposed to be so extraordinary smart, he sure was the biggest idiot. There! I've said it. I had issues reconciling the hours he was putting into work with any social life what-so-ever, no matter how minuscule. Especially given the multitude of health issues.Look, I didn’t hate Jude. But I don’t know, he was a caricature of misery. I don’t quite know how to put it into words. While reading A Little Life, I felt like a voyeur, looking from outside in, without getting too involved, even though my heart should have been broken, which it was, in a cerebral and perplexed way, but not a visceral one. I guess my main problem with this novel was that Jude’s relationships were not believable. Call me a cynic. Most situations were not believable. A Franciscan monastery of men given a baby to look after? Oh, I didn't realise the book was taking place in the 18th century or earlier. Also, there is no way in hell he could be so proficient/masterful at so many things, especially when he'd been abandoned and abused at a very young age. Those things happening in early childhood tend to mess up one's brain neurodevelopment, one would be lucky to be average. (plenty of scientific lit on it, read it, if you don't believe me). The writing wasn't terrible, it wasn't exceptional either, as little is shown, most is told to us. Again and again. I didn't underline any paragraphs. Given its length, it didn't take me long to finish it, so I guess it had a relatively good flow, although many parts were boring, repetitive and at times I was screaming in my head "can we get on with it"? This novel could have been tighter by getting rid of 100 pages or more, but its length wasn't the biggest problem. So, while I appreciate the hard work Yanagihara must have put into writing this novel and while I really wanted to like it, I just didn't connect with the characters, I found them cartoonish and there was no character growth. Some sort of redemption, even some revenge would have made this novel a little better.Also - nitpicking here - I found it extremely disappointing that given his profession and affluence, Jude never really did anything to help kids in a similar situation with his. Even if it was from a distance, he could have done more, much more. Had Yanagihara been more restrained when dishing out the tragedies and/or the virtues, the novel would have been so much more potent, as it would have been more credible. All that misery bestowed upon poor Jude made me think of some of the worst new adult novels I was reading a year + ago. I expect more from literary fiction....more

The main protagonist is Casey Edwards, who's spent 10 years locked up in a mental institution. She's got a usual case of total amnesia. One comes across amnesia in soap operas and books relatively often, as it adds to the drama. But the thing is, amnesia, especially total amnesia is extremely rare. So I had to work on suspending my disbelief.Since I haven't read many books in this genre, it's a bit difficult to compare and contrast. It was an easy read, that got better after the 10%. The writing was simple and the pace was fast, at times dizzying, with multiple narrators in play. There are lots of flashbacks and dreams, which I guess it was to be expected given Casey's amnesia.Things were quite twisted, but nevertheless it was relatively easy to guess who'd done it. author: Wood, Fiona
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4-4.5 starsCloudwish is a delightful, gentle young adult novel, that brings forward a female character who's non-Caucasian, so that alone was refreshi4-4.5 starsCloudwish is a delightful, gentle young adult novel, that brings forward a female character who's non-Caucasian, so that alone was refreshing. Vân Uoc Phan is the Australian-born daughter of Vietnamese refugees. They're poor and live in a government-owned, high rise apartment in Melbourne, Australia.Vân Uoc Phan, whose name means Cloudwish, has a scholarship at a prestigious, private high-school, where she makes herself inconspicuous as to not attract the unwanted attention of the rich, mean kids. She's a top student, excellent oboe player and a wanna-be artist, despite her parents' wishes that she'd become a successful/rich lawyer or doctor. From a distance, and in spite of her better judgment, she fancies Billy, top alpha, good looking male specimen, who's on the school's prestigious rowing team. She knows he's arrogant and a bit of a bully, but she's also seen a better side of him. She daydreams/wishes that Billy would fancy her and suddenly, out of nowhere, he starts falling for her, which she finds disconcerting. I thought Fiona Wood did a wonderful job describing Vân Uoc's struggles to fit in, while staying true to herself. But who was she? She felt caught in the middle between her Australian-ess and her Vietnamese heritage.I loved that Fiona Wood brought forward a very relevant and current issue/situation - that of refugees and of what is abysmally called by our disgraceful government, boat people. Reading about Vân Uoc's situation and especially about her parents' horrific story was heartbreaking.This was a very well written, enjoyable, yet compelling novel, that's got teenage angst relating to fitting in, achieving, making decisions and first love. On top of that, there are a few extra layers about class, about opportunities, about immigrants'/refugees' issues and about post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). And I couldn't help but love all the many Jane Eyre references and the fact that Vân Uoc considered her a role model of sorts.I received this novel via Netgalley. Many thanks to the publishers, Macmillan Australia, for the opportunity to read and .Cover: 5 stars. ...more

title: King of Hearts        (Hearts, #3)

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I dropped whatever I was reading when my pre-ordered KoH made its way on my Kindle. So, yeah, I was keen to read it. I enjoyed this new installment inI dropped whatever I was reading when my pre-ordered KoH made its way on my Kindle. So, yeah, I was keen to read it. I enjoyed this new installment in the Hearts Series, I finished it in one day.CharactersI liked our heroine, Alexis, she was spontaneous and didn't mix her words. She's a working-class girl who's got a job in the City, working for the stiffs of the financial world. I approved ;-) of her opinions on the banking/financial system as they pretty much match mine. Of course, our hero, Oliver King (love the name) is hot, smart and a nice boss, which made for a nice change, as in the majority of the romance novels the hot bosses are always grumpy and overbearing. And he kind of lacks tact, especially when it comes to Alexis.LH Cosway's writing is fluid and well paced. She does first person narrations very well. For me, the best part about Ms. Cosway's books is that her characters, especially the female ones, are a bit different, not cookie cutter beautiful and most importantly, they usually have sparkling personalities. In saying all the above, I did have a few little grumbles that nagged at me from time to time:- I've never been to Rome, but I'm pretty sure there are no beaches within walking distance. - I didn't find it believable that a skilled professional like King would make comments on Alexis' appearance in the interview, especially when others were present.- I doubt that somebody as busy and important as King would have both assistants go for lunch at the same time. From experience, that doesn't really happen.- the modelling session, while cute and all, again, I had trouble believing that someone of his standing would allow photos of him, with his PA!, be published. In the business world where appearance is everything, somebody as driven as King, who wanted everyone's approval, would not be so silly. Just saying.- I did struggle a lot with Oliver's disappearance and I thought it was out of character and not very believable that he wouldn't have heard that his mum was still alive and that he didn't kill his father like he assumed. Surely, given the high profile of all involved, that would have been in the news? So, yeah, while I appreciate that we needed the drama, that aspect of the book, didn't sit well with me. I struggled to believe it.But in saying all the above, I still enjoyed this novel. I thought it was better than the previous "Hearts of Fire", but my favourite in the series is still "Six of Hearts". Will I be reading the next book in the series? I sure will.Recommended: To everyone.Cover: 3 stars because  I'm so over half naked men on covers. ...more

title: What Milo Saw
author: Macgregor, Virginia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've received this novel via Netgalley in exchange for an honest .Honestly, I'm not quite sure how to rate this novel. It's got all the ingredieI've received this novel via Netgalley in exchange for an honest .Honestly, I'm not quite sure how to rate this novel. It's got all the ingredients that usually work on/for me: a precocious child, family problems, older people, a refugee, unexpected acts of kindness and it's even written in the third person. In many ways, it's very similar to one of my favourite books-  My Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She's Sorry by Fredrik Backman. But I didn't like it as much as the one mentioned above. Milo, our protagonist, is 9 years-old and he suffers from a degenerative eye disease, that will eventually render him blind.He's a bit of a loner; he lives with his unhappy, recently separated mum, and his father's 92-year-old grandmother, whom Milo loves dearly, but who's not easy to look after. After a fire incident, Sandy, Milo's mum decides to put Gran into a nursing home.  Things start to unravel from them on, as Milo misses his Gran very much and is determined to bring her back home. His eyesight may be diminishing, but he's very good at noticing things that most people don't. And he notices that things weren't quite as they seemed at Forget Me Not - the nursery home where Gran was living. Will Milo be able to get Gran back home? I thought the writing was strong and very competent. The narration alternates between Milo, who's the main storyteller and Gran, Milo's mum, Sandy and Tripi, the Syrian refugee cook at Forget Me Not.In my opinion, Sandy and Gran's POVs didn't add too much to the story and weren't terribly insightful. I think, if taken out, the pace of the story would have been a bit better, as at times, it felt a bit sluggish. A couple of times I did think that Milo sounded way too grown-up. I also had a bit of an issue with the pet pig, as I didn't find it very believable that Milo would be able to get away with hiding it under his coat without anyone noticing at the nursing home. Also, he leaves Hamlet, the pig, with Gran and for a couple of days nobody notices anything? A bit hard to believe. How about its bodily functions? How about food, don't they eat a lot? Hamlet sounded more like a cat. It's probably just me, I'm sure many won't have any issues with the pet pig.While visiting Gran, Milo meets Tripi, the cook. A friendship of sorts ensues. Other secondary characters come on board, one of them being Al/Clouds, a relative from Scotland, who's an undercover journalist and who's paying rent to live in Gran's room in Milo and his mum's place.Things get worse before they get better.This is a good novel.Many will find it heart-warming and emotional. But that's just the thing. Given the plot and the characters, I should have been an emotional wreck, because it really had themes that really tug at my heartstrings, but "What Milo Saw" didn't quite manage to do that.Nevertheless, it's still a 3.5 - 4 stars novel. Looking forward to seeing other readers' opinion.Recommended: If you liked  My Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She's Sorry and if you like feel good stories with precocious kids.Cover: 5 stars...more

review: The novel begins with beautiful descriptions of the Sweet Oak River in the Ozarks region, somewhere in Kansas. Ruby, a seventy-eight-year-old and her The novel begins with beautiful descriptions of the Sweet Oak River in the Ozarks region, somewhere in Kansas. Ruby, a seventy-eight-year-old and her granddaughter, Tulsa (grr, the name), twenty-seven, live by the river and run a business renting out canoes and a few chalets. Their business is struggling. But somehow the bank is lending them six hundred thousand to buy a neighbour’s property. Right, it's fiction. The new loan puts even more pressure on them to get enough clients in order to make repayments. Tulsa is feeling stressed. Despite her grandmother’s pestering, she’s got no time or disposition for romance. Besides, she still remembers her now deceased mom’s heartbreak following the breakup of several relationships.This novel is not just about Tulsa and her grandmother. Pearl, Ruby’s friend, is a deeply religious widow, who struggles to accept her grandson's homosexuality. Then here's BJ, who used to be Tulsa's mum’s best friend when they were young. Her son, Guy, is now working with Ruby and Tulsa and is thought to be Tulsa's half brother.And Jen, Tulsa’s friend, a twenty-nine-year-old manicurist, who has dreams of getting married and starting a family with her boyfriend.We get to learn about each character in separate chapters. All the women come together to a romance novel book club initiated by Ruby. Somehow, the romance novels the women are reading propel them to make changes with their lives or look at things differently.There was one line in this novel that I highlighted; when BJ, a hypochondriac, sees the doctor yet again, he recommends her to get a life and find a man. Astonished by the suggestion, she says: “Jesus loves me.” The doctor’s reply: “Jesus loves everybody, …, you need someone less promiscuous.” Reading the Sweet Oak is a charming, well-written novel, with endearing female characters of different ages and backgrounds, who grow and change, as the novel comes to its conclusion. 3.5 starsCover: 4 starsI've received this novel via NetGalley, in exchange for an honest . review: 3-3.5 starsIf I Fall, If I Die is the story of eleven-year-old Will and his mum, Diane, who's an agoraphobic. Will can't remember ever being Outside. 3-3.5 starsIf I Fall, If I Die is the story of eleven-year-old Will and his mum, Diane, who's an agoraphobic. Will can't remember ever being Outside. For most of his life, he's been content to stay Inside, make masterpieces and other bits and pieces, and just keeping his mum company. This novel has an interesting premise and plot. I love novels where the main characters are kids, as looking at the world through their eyes is always interesting. So I feel like I should have liked this novel a lot more than I have. The beginning showed quite a lot of promise. But a quarter in, I felt like I was stuck as it didn't feel like I was progressing at all. This novel felt much longer than its less than 300 pages.But in saying all the above, it wasn't a bad read. The writing was very competent; there were some quirky bits that I quite liked, and even the plot had an interesting turn. It's always hard to articulate the failings of an adeptly written, with quirky characters and an interesting plot - the perfect recipe, some would say. The only thing I could come up with is that I felt disengaged or better said not as engaged as I should have been. Regardless, Christie's talent is obvious, so I'm looking forward to his next writing adventure.I've received this novel via NetGalley, in exchange for an honest ....more

title: All Involved
author: Gattis, Ryan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've received this novel from Netgalley, in exchange of an honest .This novel is a hard one to rate as it's like nothing I've read before, but wI've received this novel from Netgalley, in exchange of an honest .This novel is a hard one to rate as it's like nothing I've read before, but while I appreciate its uniqueness (to me), I'm not sure I liked it that much. Sure, this is not a novel you like and I dare say want to re-read, but was it a good one?First of all, a warning: it's gruesome! The violence is astonishing. There is lots of it but because of the way it was presented, it sort of became cartoonish, and I felt somewhat desensitised or rather not as affected by it as I would normally be. It takes a lot for me to become desensitised to violence, as I avoid consuming it via the media.All Involved is written in the first person, from many different perspectives, the majority of them, Latino gang members. The Los Angeles riots of the 1992 serve as the background for the gangland wars that ensue, following the brutal killing of a civilian young man, Ernesto, the sibling of two members of one of the Latino gangs. To be honest, the first chapter discombobulated me, because here we had Ernesto, rambling on about his job and dreams and as he was walking home and then we read his report of the violence that he himself is subjected to. And then, bam, he dies. I didn't see that coming, the death of a narrator that is. Ernesto is killed. We move on, to another character's narration, and that's Lupe, aka Payasa, Ernesto's sister, who finds out about Ernesto's demise. So, revenge and retaliation are planned while Ernesto's body is left in an alley for the police to find. Except that police and other authorities are too busy with the riots.And on and on it goes. More characters, more violence.Look, the narrative structure was unusual, given the many first person POVs.Many a times I found myself thinking that it didn't sound genuine, that no Latino gangster would sound/think like that. I know, it's silly and presumptuous of me to think like that, given that I'm your stereotypical middle-class white woman, who has never had any encounters or known any gang members, not to mention that I live in Australia. But without knowing anything about the author and his background, I just felt like here we have yet another white person trying to give voice to a person diametrically different to his background and race. What I'm trying to say is that I just didn't connect and didn't sympathize at all with any of the characters because they didn't feel authentic. Sure, Ryan Gattis threw in some swearing and some Spanish words, but I was still not sold on the authenticity front. I thought "All Involved" was more of a voyeuristic exercise in gang violence, without much depth. Ryan Gattis missed the mark when it came to creating fully developed characters, who would lead us to some sort of thoughtful analysis on the society, on race relations, gangs, and even the riots, especially when the blurb is putting the LA riots front and center.Recommended: Sure. It's an interesting novel, albeit extremely violent.Cover(s): 4 stars...more

This novel is about women; it's aboI've received this novel through NetGalley, thanks to Diversion publishing for the opportunity to read and . This novel is about women; it's about sisters and sisterhood. Our protagonists are four very different women, who come together after one of them had placed an ad in the local book store's newsletter. What makes them similar is the loneliness and the search for something else, for more. There were many good things about this novel. I liked that the women were very different, in age, occupations and backgrounds. I liked that none of them was perfect. I liked that it wasn't overly sugary and that there was conflict. And I loved it that they overcome the misunderstandings and resentment to stay friends.Regardless, at times I felt disconnected, like I was looking in from the outside. I didn't care much for the first person alternate povs of each of the ladies. Occasionally, I thought I was reading somebody's pov, but few paragraphs in, I'd realise it was somebody else's. I hope that's just the case for the draft version I received, and that more obvious delineations between the different characters' narratives will be introduced for the published work. Each of the main chapters starts with the name of the each of the women and a novel next to it. Which I thought it peculiar, since there are no other references to those books. So that was kind of pointless, because there's no way someone would have read or heard of all those novels, especially since they're all contemporaries. I love stories about women, women's issues, about women coming together and sticking to each other through thick and thin. But although this novel was about all that, I didn't connect emotionally with any of the characters. So for that reason, I'm giving it 3.5 stars.Cover: 4 stars...more

author: Daly, Paula*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4-4.5 starsI received this novel through Netgalley, in exchange for an honest ."Bodies are my business. Living, not dead." Great opening, I thou4-4.5 starsI received this novel through Netgalley, in exchange for an honest ."Bodies are my business. Living, not dead." Great opening, I thought. This was quite a gripping page turner. To be honest, I hadn't paid attention to the blurb, so it sort of took me by surprise. In a nice way. Especially given that it was a psychological suspense-thriller, which is not something I indulge in very often.The Mistake I Made is very well written. It's tight, without any unnecessary flourishes. While I've confessed I'm not the biggest fan of the first person narratives, in this case, it was necessary and very well done. This way, we got to understand our heroine better. Roz is very relatable; she's an average single mother, who struggles to pay her debts, in spite of working hard as a physiotherapist. Speaking of her profession, I appreciated learning a few things about the body from the physiotherapist's point of view.I thought it was quite accurate and detailed. It turns out Ms Daly had worked as a physiotherapist. Talk about writing about what you know. But do not worry, it's not a physiotherapy manual and it's not going to drown you in too much jargon. I noticed it and wanted to mention it. Moving on. What I enjoyed the most about this novel was the psychological aspects and the character development. Also the tone was quite different. It felt as if you were having a candid, straight forward conversation with someone close, while being empathetic but also somewhat detached. I can't quite articulate it.I liked Roz. She wasn't perfect, but she wasn't the worst person either. Just like most of us. I'm sure many people will have issues with the infidelity/prostitution in this novel. It wasn't the case for me. After all it's an important part of the plot. Actions have consequences. And Roz sure gets to pay for her actions. Luckily, it's not all gloom and doom. There's redemption and hope.While I don't have much to compare it against, as I rarely read this genre, I enjoyed reading this novel and I thought it was very well written and edited.Recommended: To the lovers of suspense, thriller with great psychological insights.Cover: 4 stars  ...more

review: I received this novel through NetGalley, thanks Booktrope for the opportunity to read and . This is an exquisitely crafted novel. It is part famI received this novel through NetGalley, thanks Booktrope for the opportunity to read and . This is an exquisitely crafted novel. It is part family saga, part romance, and it's set during the interbellum, in the good old American South, in all its racist, ignorant "glory". It's uncanny to notice that things haven't changed that much in the last 80-90 years - but I digress.In the beginning we are introduced to four different characters: an African-American girl, Jeselle; Nathaniel, a piano virtuoso; Lydia, a recently widowed mother of two; and Whitmore, a white teenage boy. As the novel progresses, all these protagonists are brought together. The synopsis says quite a lot, so I won't go over it myself. I will just say that it was a very well written novel. Tess Thompson has created beautiful, three-dimensional characters, who are very realistic. Their stories and the plot are very believable and compelling. The title itself is very evocative and I like it a lot. A truly remarkable read!Recommended: To lovers of historic fiction and those who enjoy literature with a good plot and well developed characters.Cover: 4.5 stars...more

Now all the women are together: Faith and her sister, Casey and her daughter, Isabella, their mother and their grandmother, who's about to turn 90.Faith meets Jake Buchanan, who was putting the final touches on the place they were renting. Jake is charming and kind and Faith feels an instant attraction and connection to him. I thought Jenny Hale did a great job articulating Faith's anguish and hurt in relation to her sister. title: Giovanni’s Room
author: Baldwin, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A few months ago, I was blown away by the documentary I Am Not Your Negro, which featured James Baldwin. I only heard of Baldwin a few years prior, viA few months ago, I was blown away by the documentary I Am Not Your Negro, which featured James Baldwin. I only heard of Baldwin a few years prior, via other GR friends' s of his books. I had his books on my TBR list, but they were there with six hundred other books ... Anyway, that documentary pushed me to seek some of his books. It didn't occur to me when watching the documentary that Baldwin was gay. The poor man, being black and gay, during a very reprehensible period in US history. Not only he had to fight against the white people, against the system because of his race, he had to hide and fight his own community's homophobia. No wonder he escaped to France for a while. Anyway, I had to remind myself that Giovanni's Room is not autobiographical, although it must have drawn inspiration from his personal experiences. I plan to read a bit more about Balwin and this novel.As I was reading Giovanni's Room I had to remind myself several times that the main character, David, an American in Paris, was a white man. David is in the closet and is ashamed by his one time encounter with a male friend. As the only child of a nice man, he feels it's his duty to be the "right" way. It's not only that, it's the 1950s and earlier, homosexuality is illegal. Paris though is more relaxed. While the cat was away, in this case, Hetta, David's fiancee, he has a dalliance with Giovanni, a beautiful and passionate Italian bartender, whom he met in a gay bar. The two have a passionate affair for a little while, even sharing Giovanni's small room. Giovanni's small, cluttered, dirty room is a metaphor of sorts for David's complex feelings, especially when he knows the time is approaching when he has to make a decision - to have a respectable life that includes a wife and kids or to give in to his preferences?It's important to remember that this was published in 1959. That's quite a feat in itself. The fact that it was written by a black man, way before the Civil movement, makes this novel even more significant.Baldwin's writing is beautifully lyrical and packaged tightly. You can sense the doubt and dread, the fear, the self-loathing. None of the male characters is likeable, that includes David himself. This is a very sad novel, albeit one beautifully written....more

title: The Readers of Broken Wheel Recommend Hardcover June 18, 2015
author: Bivald, Katarina*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 starsI received this book through NetGalley. Thanks to the Random House UK for the opportunity to read and . Sara from Sweden ends up in Bro3.5 starsI received this book through NetGalley. Thanks to the Random House UK for the opportunity to read and . Sara from Sweden ends up in Broken Wheel, Iowa, after years of corresponding with Amy. Sara is a very plain twenty something year-old, who prefers books to people. This novel was slow churning, especially in the beginning. But that conveyed very well the slow pace of a half-dead town, and the despondent outlooks of our heroine and most people in Broken Wheel. On top of that, everyone is pretty sad about Amy's death, especially her handsome nephew, Tom.As you can guess from the title, the books are an integral part of this novel. Most books mentioned are familiar, popular titles. Most of titles are American, with a few Jane Austen and the Bronte Sisters thrown in. I personally would have liked to hear about some more Scandinavian authors, besides Stieg Larsson. Look, the book was a bit dull at times. I don't know if it was deliberate, but it was fitting. After all, Broken Wheel is a dying town. Its inhabitants don't have much to look forward to. There are no jobs, most young people had moved to bigger cities. Sara is a bit lost, with no one really carrying about her or vice-versa. All she's got are her books. Sara's arrival gives the good people of Broken Wheel something to talk about and something to do, because they want to make her feel welcome and maybe have her stay in town. The pace picks up once Sarah settles more and gets to know the people of Broken Wheel.This is an interesting novel, that talks about books and the importance of books. It's no The Shadows of the Wind by Carlos Ruiz Zafon, but it was an easy and enjoyable read. More than about the books, it's a novel about small towns, about finding meaning and being able to connect. I liked it because of its different tone. Also, I liked that most people were ordinary and plain, none more so than our heroine. I find that stimulating, just because it was contrary to the established "beautiful heroines" that you find in most women's fiction novels. Conclusion: An enjoyable debut novel from Katarina Bivald. Recommended: To those who enjoy books about books.Cover: 4.5 stars...more

review: 4 starsI received this book through NetGalley from Penguin Books Australia, so here's my honest .This is book about Sully, a somewhat charismati4 starsI received this book through NetGalley from Penguin Books Australia, so here's my honest .This is book about Sully, a somewhat charismatic 39 year old, who hasn't achieved anything of note in his life - a loser of sorts. He's overweight, divorced with no children, no job, no place to live and no friends who want to hear from him. There's nothing worth living for, so he decides to kill himself. But that's yet another thing to add to his long list of failures and disappointments, as he wakes up in a hospital. While in hospital, he realises that he could do something useful for once by donating a kidney. So he embarks on a quest to doing just that. Things sort of line-up for Sully, as he finds a flat to live in, in exchange for looking after an old dog, whose owner had passed away. The deceased's daughter, Natalie, is happy to have someone to look after the dog, while she arranges for the apartment to be sold and someone to look after the dog.It turns out that becoming a donor is not easy, and Sully has to have psychological assessments and a multitude of medical tests before a committee decides if he's fit to donate. While going through the process of becoming a donor, Sully starts a new life, because he's got a purpose. We get to meet different characters: Natalie, a 35 year old radio producer, who's a divorced mother of an 8 year old boy and living with her overbearing mother. Tim, Sully's childhood friend, is a very rich and successful banker, whose marriage is on the rocks. The other more secondary characters are well drawn and they all have a role to play in Sully's story.This was a well written book, where all characters are everyday people, not exceptional but not ordinary either - people we all know. Everybody's got a story. Also, nobody's life is really what they hoped it would be. People do and say shitty things. But most people need to be heard, seen and need to find a purpose in life. I didn't find this book humorous in any way, which doesn't mean that it wasn't a good book. I liked that most of the characters were flawed, especially Sullivan. Thank goodness most things work out, and that Sully redeems himself, because otherwise I would have been a bit depressed. But don't let that put you off reading it, because it's a good novel.Recommended: Sure.Cover:: 4+ stars ...more

review: I'm jumping with joy and exhilaration having just finished a charming and very delightful novel. Exactly what I was after! A perfect Sunday afternoon I'm jumping with joy and exhilaration having just finished a charming and very delightful novel. Exactly what I was after! A perfect Sunday afternoon companion. Well, a perfect companion, regardless of the day of the week or season. I loved everything about the Red Notebook. The writing is simple but has a beautiful flow. The main characters, Laurent and Laure, are well drawn and interesting. It was refreshing to read a romantic book with middle-aged protagonists. The plot was lovely and romantic, in a realistic way.As you can imagine, since the male protagonist owns a bookshop, books and authors make an appearance. C'est incroyable! No mention of any of the Bronte sisters or Jane Austen novels, or the Great Gatsby or the Catcher in the Rye. I'll drink to that! In case you're wondering, I do not have anything against the above authors or novels, I've read and enjoyed them all, I am just tired of seeing them mentioned in so many novels. Thanks to Antoine Laurain, many known and less known French authors are mentioned. I've added a few more books to my ever growing to-be-read list.The Red Notebook is not a literary masterpiece, but it's well written and has a huge dose of French charm. It would make for a great script for a cute chick-flick (preferably in French).I'll be making sure to read Antoine Laurain's other novel.If you're after something light and romantic, but not stupid, sweet but not saccharin(ny), the Red Notebook is the perfect novel.I've received this novel via Netgalley, in exchange for an honest . title: My Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She's Sorry
author: Backman, Fredrik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 5 Stars + This is one of the most beautiful books I’ve ever read!!! I only requested it on NetGalley because I liked the cover and this one was also  5 Stars + This is one of the most beautiful books I’ve ever read!!! I only requested it on NetGalley because I liked the cover and this one was also under the Women’s Fiction/Literature category so I thought why not. Many thanks to Atria Books for providing this ARC. So I came to read this book without having any preconceptions or expectations, as I hadn’t heard of Fredrik Backman or his previous novel. And how I love it when I am pleasantly surprised! The title alone is quirky and different. I’m pretty sure it’s one of the longest novel titles I’ve ever come across.“Every seven-year-old deserves a superhero. That’s just how it is. Anyone who doesn’t agree needs their head examined.” I was hooked. Almost instantly. And it only got better and better after that.The story is told in the third person (and how I love this!), from the precocious Elsa's perspective. She loves words, correct spelling, and “she knows she’s different”. Also, she’s a very lonely girl, whose only friend is her seventy-seven-year-old maternal grandmother. Her unorthodox, politically incorrect, retired doctor grandmother likes to smoke indoors and to cause mischief at every opportunity. They both adore each other. Grandma encourages Elsa to stay different. At night, she tells Elsa stories, in the Land of Almost-Awake and the Kingdom of Miamas, where everybody is different and nobody is normal.Unfortunately, grandma dies. She leaves Elsa a quest of sorts: delivering letters to different people to say sorry for past grievances. And this is how Elsa gets to know all her neighbours and she also learns some valuable lessons. I don’t want to say too much because of spoilers. You should really read it for yourself. It’s magical, quirky, funny, charming and very well written. I loved the tone of the narration, the mystical fairytales intermingling with reality. Elsa’s observations are just precious, candid and wonderfully endearing. Certain parts of the novel made me think of the French movie, Amelie, and also of another marvellous book, Sophie’s World, written by the Norwegian, Jostein Gaarder. I can only imagine how amazing the Swedish version must be, but kudos to the translator, Henning Koch, for doing such a great job.I loved so many things about this novel. There’s so much one can draw from it. But ultimately, it’s about daring to be different, about being seen and heard, about love, redemption, and forgiveness. It’s also about the importance of grandparents. I had a wonderful grandmother, who was a bit unusual.And because I love this book so much, I am going to buy the paperback, as this is a book that I want to re-read and give special friends. I believe in gifting good books. This one is definitely in the "great books" category. Recommended: ABSOLUTELY!!!! If you’ve had a special grandparent; if you like whimsy; if you like smart and most importantly, different, than this book is for you. Cover: 5 stars...more

author: Coetzee, J.M.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I forget that not everyone has a potty mouth like I do, soDISCLAIMER a little bit of cussing coming up. Disgrace was quite a challenging read, not becI forget that not everyone has a potty mouth like I do, soDISCLAIMER a little bit of cussing coming up. Disgrace was quite a challenging read, not because of the writing, which was excellent, but because of its content.Arguably, it wasn't the best time to read this kind of novel. This is a complex novel about post-Apartheid South Africa, where things are changing at a fast pace. This is about race relations, about men and women, fathers and daughters, about city vs country and so much more.Professor David Laurie is fifty-two, twice divorced. His dalliance with a twenty-year-old is his professional undoing, as he is fired from the University. He takes refuge on his daughter's farm, in the East Cape region.I disliked Laurie a great deal. He's an intellectual with no depth, no self-awareness, a misogynist, who sees women exclusively as sex objects. And doesn't he go on and on about women's appearance, the entitled white, swine man. Because a woman's beauty does not belong to her alone. It is a part of the bounty she brings into the world. She has a duty to share it.  I found myself saying "FU, Professor" many times and wishing all kinds of misfortunes come upon him. And they did come. Some horrendous things happen to him and his daughter. His relationship with his daughter is tenuous and strange. He doesn't really know her. He's such a shallow man, he couldn't even see his own daughter past her looks. FU, Professor.He did try to help her once they went through the horrific event, but it wasn't easy, as Lucy is stubborn and unrelenting - to be honest, her choices didn't make sense to me in any way, I couldn't find any logical justification to her action or inaction, as it may be. Let's just say that she lacked that primal instinct that makes one run away from danger.There is so much to unpack and analyse. The fact that Coetzee managed to fit so much in such a short novel is quite the accomplishment. It sure made my blood boil at times, so I guess that makes it a good novel, even though my reactions were unpleasant and uncomfortable for the most part....more

title: The Children Act
author: McEwan, Ian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ian McEwan, you're killing me! How does he do it? No idea. He's just on another level, isn't he? Deeply observant, realistic, and interesting, his wriIan McEwan, you're killing me! How does he do it? No idea. He's just on another level, isn't he? Deeply observant, realistic, and interesting, his writing is sublime. Fiona Maye is an almost sixty-year-old High Court Family Judge. She's well suited for the position: she's intelligent, pragmatic, patient and calm. When her husband of twenty-something years decides he needs a break to have a new sexual encounter with a twenty-something-year-old, Fiona finds herself experiencing a variety of feelings: shock, incredulity, distress, anger and so on. McEwan masterfully unpeels Fiona's quandaries. As if her personal life being in turmoil wasn't enough, she's supposed to give a judgment in a rather tricky case, where an almost eighteen-year-old boy and his parents, devout Jehovah Witnesses refuse blood transfusion which is absolutely necessary in order to have a chance to cure his leukemia.Besides this more important case and its consequences, McEwan introduces a few other cases, with different degrees of detail. Occasionally, I got a bit bored and I thought they were excessive and could have been cut without affecting the story. Regardless of the above-mentioned grumble, The Children Act was compelling, sophisticated, and awfully realistic.4.5 starsAUDIOBOOK: Excellent audiobook, narrated by Lindsay Duncan...more

title: Big Little Lies
author: Moriarty, Liane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It looks like I'm the last person around to read a Liane Moriarty novel. Even people whom I wouldn't call readers have read at least one of her novelsIt looks like I'm the last person around to read a Liane Moriarty novel. Even people whom I wouldn't call readers have read at least one of her novels. Anyway, I'm late for the party, but I've made it.I'll try to keep my  short as there are lots of them out there. As you can tell from my rating, I liked it. A lot. Despite its deceptive simplicity, it was a clever, extremely clever novel. The character development was exceptional. It all felt very real and so familiar. My kids are in primary school, so many characters and situations were relatable. In this novel, Moriarty pretty much covered most of the female archetypes, from the stay-at-home domestic goddesses to the single mothers and the corporate types. Aren't we a crazy, wonderful, unexpected bunch?!? Another clever thing about this novel was its structure. I'm not sure if it's unique, but I've never come across it before. Quite early on we know somebody has died. There are police interviews, snippets with witnesses, intercalated with chapters of events prior to the "big night" - the fundraising trivia night for the primary school.This was definitely a fascinating, interesting read, which I thought was an accurate representation of a certain echelon of the middle class, Australian suburbia. In the end, what came through for me was that we all have shit (pardon my French) to deal with, nobody's life is perfect and you never know what happens behind closed doors....more

title: The Light Between Oceans
author: Stedman, M.L.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is too big a novel to do it justice with my poorly articulated . So, I'll just write down a few things. First of all, I can't get my head aThis is too big a novel to do it justice with my poorly articulated . So, I'll just write down a few things. First of all, I can't get my head around this being a debut novel. I was captivated from the first paragraph. The writing has such a beautiful flow, the descriptions are so vivid. The third person narration is used masterfully, there are no unreliable narrators, we get to know the inner thoughts, feelings and history of most characters.Our main hero, Tom Sherbourne, is an actual World War I hero. Like most men who have returned from the war, he's struggling with living and not letting his demons consume him. So he focuses on living simply, day by day. He'd rather be by himself, which makes becoming a lighthouse keeper the perfect occupation for him. When he gets to travel all the way to the South West of Australia, he meets a beautiful and very lively young woman, Isabel Graysmark. She takes a liking to him, and he's fascinated with her, and can't quite comprehend that someone like her would be interested in him. Isabel knows what she wants: she wants to marry Tom and have a big family. She's never been on Janus Island where Tom is a lightkeeper, but she's not afraid to live life in isolation. Unfortunately, the poor Isabel suffers three miscarriages. She's absolutely distraught about it. One day, a boat with a dead man and a crying baby drifts onshore the island. Isabel takes to looking after the baby, while Tom buries the man. She's besotted with the little, sweet baby girl. She persuades Tom not to report it and raise the baby as their own. The baby enriches their life and gets under Tom's skin, melting his cold and broken heart. (view spoiler)[But when they find out that the baby's mother is still alive and looking for Lucy, Tom grapples with their decision. His conscience tells him to rectify their wrong, but Isabel won't hear about it.A few years go by. Eventually, Tom and Isabel are apprehended and Lucy returned to her biological mother. (hide spoiler)]There is so much angst, and pain, and worries and most people involved are suffering. The situation is dreadful for all concerned. At times, it's absolutely heartwrenching. M.L. Stedman crafted such a beautiful novel, which, I dare say, will become a classic. The writing, the plot, the characters are exquisite. The setting enhances the sense of loneliness, doom and gives the decisions a different weight.Tom Sherbourne is one of the most wholesome male characters ever created. Even his name sounds wholesome. This story will stay with me for a long time.Cover: 5 stars ...more

title: A Man Called Ove
author: Backman, Fredrik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: God damn it, Fredrik Backman, what are you doing to me? First 'My Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She's Sorry' and now this one? I'm a bit of a mess,God damn it, Fredrik Backman, what are you doing to me? First 'My Grandmother Asked Me to Tell You She's Sorry' and now this one? I'm a bit of a mess, as I've just finished reading 'A Man Called Ove' and I'm sad. This was an incredibly touching novel. And so unique. For starters, the protagonist is a man who's almost 60 years old; he's quite unlikable. He's one of those grumpy old men, that we've all encountered. He's taciturn, abrupt, very strict when it comes to rules and regulations. But he's actually a very modest man, a hard worker, a man of few words, a man who's always done what's right. He was a devoted husband to the love of his life, Sonja, but now he's a widower. And he's kind of had enough of living. I love Fredrick Backman's writing. It's succinct, without many flourishes yet it does the job. Backman is a masterful user of the third person narration. As for his characters, many of them are unique and imperfectly quirky.Backman is a fantastic storyteller, with a keen understanding of the human condition. He believes in inter-connectivity and community, he believes in family, in whatever forms it may come. You can tell that Backman has a high regard for people past their prime. I dig that. Big time! 'A Man Called Ove' is a splendid novel. It's poignant, heart-warming and compelling. Cover: 5 stars...more

review: 4 starsI received this book via Netgalley for an honest .This is an impressive debut novel from Tess Woods. It deals with themes that are a bit 4 starsI received this book via Netgalley for an honest .This is an impressive debut novel from Tess Woods. It deals with themes that are a bit uncomfortable for many of us - adultery. But we all know it happens. I thought it was a well-written book. Both protagonists, the 37 year-old General Practitioner (GP) Mel and the 28 year old physiotherapist, Matt, alternate telling their story. It's a story about insta-lust, that quickly becomes love. Mel and Matt feel like they're soul-mates. But, life is complicated: Mel has been married for 14 years to a very nice man and has two teenage kids. Matt is engaged to get married. Add to this the age difference and living thousands of kilometres apart, and you have the perfect recipe for disaster. They both become obsessed with each other. So Matt breaks up his engagement and travels to Perth to track Mel down. What ensues is a passionate encounter over 6 days. But Mel is torn between family and intense, passionate love. The author is very good at conveying her anguish and desperation.I don't want to say more because of spoilers.But I will say that this novel is different and that the ending is unpredictable, but I thought that made the novel even more realistic. Looking forward to reading the next Tess Woods novel. Recommended: To those who'd like something different, not necessarily HEA, but very realistic.Cover: 4+ stars...more

I think this was the first "Australian3.5 Outback StarsI have received this book from Random House Australia, through Netgalley, for a honest . I think this was the first "Australian outback" book I've ever read. To be honest, I didn't think I'd like it, but I was pleasantly surprised. This is a feel-good, heartwarming story, set in the central New South Whales, Australia. The male protagonist, Ewan Mackenzie, is a hard-working man, who's trying to save his farm and help his brother's widow, Trish, and her two twin boys. He thinks he's undeserving of love because he feels guilt over his brother's untimely death. But a beautiful American girl, Kree, shows up in their part of their world, as Ewan and other locals are looking for her brother who got lost in the bush. They're both attracted to each other, but for different reasons, they try to deny it. But life comes full circle.Alissa Callen writes well and the novel had a good flow and it's an easy read. The characters are interesting and believable. In saying all that, the plot and the ending were predictable or shall I say a bit too in the end, everything fits together perfectly , but I guess that goes with with the genre. Recommended: For those who enjoy a feel-good rural story that is un-challenging and has a HEA ending.Cover: 3+ stars...more

review: 3-3.5 starsI got this book via Netgalley. I read the blurb and thought: this is right up my alley. I like realistic contemporary fiction about women a3-3.5 starsI got this book via Netgalley. I read the blurb and thought: this is right up my alley. I like realistic contemporary fiction about women and women's issues. I have very mixed feelings about this novel. I have no idea how to rate it.The writing wasn't terrible. But it felt like reading a journal, or better said, a calendar, filled with the everyday mundanities, without much introspection or charm. Of course, that felt very realistic, and I could empathise, but it just felt dry. I found myself getting bored and reading the novel felt like work. It was just like having someone tell you every detail of one of their day, which is very similar to yours. And when you think your own life is not that interesting or exceptional, why would you want to hear about the minutiae of their day.So I don't know, maybe there was a case of too much realism and not enough escapism?I should have loved this book, but while I didn't hate it, it didn't grab me as much as it should have, in spite of its relatability.Recommended: To those who want to read something very realistic and very relatable. title: Quicksand
author: Toltz, Steve
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 starsSteve Tolz’s previous novel was highly praised by many and it is on my very long to-be-read list; so, I had to request his latest when I noti3.5 starsSteve Tolz’s previous novel was highly praised by many and it is on my very long to-be-read list; so, I had to request his latest when I noticed it on NetGalley. Thanks to Simon&Schuster for the opportunity to read and  Quicksand.This was an unusual novel, like nothing I’ve ever read before. I’m not even sure if I liked it or not. It’s the story of two unlikely friends: Liam, a failed writer and policeman and Aldo, a very unlucky man, who’s more of a criminal entrepreneur. They’ve been friends since highschool. Quicksand was an interesting read. On many occasions, I thought “this is brilliant”. There is a lot of humour, mostly dark. Aldo’s fast-paced quips are entertaining and depressing at the same time. He’s a master nihilist. True, life hasn’t been very kind to him. Unfortunately, on too many occasions I felt disengaged, and I had to concentrate to keep up either with some of Aldo’s never-ending musings or the very detailed and mundane descriptions of inconsequent life snippets, that were going nowhere in particular. I thought some of the chapters could have done with some polishing and, especially, condensing. There were lots of witty observations. I wish I’d highlighted some of them. "I'm nobody's muse" comes to mind.Quicksand was dazzling and very infuriating at the same time. It was humours and also depressing. It was fast paced but also slow churning. At times I loved it; sometimes I struggled.It’s obvious that Steve Tolz is a brilliant writer. I'm somewhat annoyed that I didn’t enjoy this novel more. It has so much potential but didn’t quite pull it off. I’m very intrigued by Steve Tolz’s writing. I can’t wait to read A Fraction of the Whole. Recommended: Sure, but it's not a book that would appeal to everyone. Cover: 3.5 stars...more

review: I've received this novel via NetGalley in exchange for an honest .Mosquitoland. I've heard of it, I wanted to read it, so when I saw it on NetGaI've received this novel via NetGalley in exchange for an honest .Mosquitoland. I've heard of it, I wanted to read it, so when I saw it on NetGalley I had to request it. The blurb sounded very interesting. The cover is absolutely gorgeous, IMHO. This was an impressive debut novel. Kudos to David Arnold for having the guts to write a teenage female character. Did he pull it off? I didn't think so. I thought the writing was pretty good; there were quite a few quotable phrases, which I forgot to highlight (ops). Then, there is the annoying 1st person narrative. And the flashbacks.And there's a road trip.I do like books about road trips. So why wasn't I totally charmed by this novel? Afterall, Mary Iris Mallone, aka MIM, is a witty, quirky, angsty sixteen-year-old girl, and I love those characteristics in a female character. The problem for me was that I just didn't find her believable. There is no way anyone, let alone a sixteen-year-old, talks/thinks like that. Nobody goes around making those kinds of observations that Mim expulses throughout the novel. I didn't connect with her at all. I had the same feelings about Beck, the guy she noticed on the Greyhound. He was too good to be true. He's only twenty-one, he's gorgeous, educated, kind hearted, principled, and totally in-tune with Mim. Mim wasn't totally in tune with herself, so I didn't find Beck credible, albeit, he was adorable and I usually dig books with nice male characters. Also, Mim's attachment to people she only just met seemed over-the-top. The interactions and few other situations seemed contrived and far-fetched.For all the novel's faults and inability to make me connect with the characters, I appreciated David Arnold writing skills and think this was a worthwhile novel to read. I am looking forward to reading his next novel because I think he's a talented writer. And I'm definitely going to look up a few of the artists he mentioned in Mosquitoland, such as Elliott Smith.Cover: 5 stars...more

review: 4 whimsical starsThis book came highly recommended. Disclaimer: I haven't read a fairytale since I was 9 or 10; I don't usually read fantasy, I don't 4 whimsical starsThis book came highly recommended. Disclaimer: I haven't read a fairytale since I was 9 or 10; I don't usually read fantasy, I don't even read vampire books. But anyway, I decided to give this one a try. I was grabbed, charmed and mesmerised from the very first paragraph. Lots of "holy shit" and "wow" were going through my head (because I am "articulate" like that ;-) ) as I was reading my way through the story. Since I don't have much experience with fantasy, saying that I have never read anything like this before won't mean much. But holy shit, the writing is amazing! I can't remember reading anywhere such long phrases, so abundant in adjectives and metaphors. You would have to work hard to find simple, ordinary sentences that are not embellished with lots of descriptive language.Catherine M. Valente's command of the English language is just uncanny. The playfulness, the imagination and quirkiness are absolutely incredible!But, towards the 75-80% I found myself getting so drowned into the language, that I couldn't quite tell what the story was about. So I can't believe I am saying this, but could this be a case of too much of a good thing? I feel extremely guilty for saying this. Very guilty, indeed.I noticed that some people put it in the children books category. They must have/know some exceptional kids, because I can bet many adults would struggle with this book. But there are enough books out there that appeal to the lowest common denominator. This is exceptional! Catherine M Valente's writing is singular!And how I wish she wrote contemporary fiction that wasn't fantasy or scifi. I would devour such books. Regardless, her writing sets the bar really high. I bow in front of such talent! Just because it's not my "cup of tea", it doesn't mean that I can't appreciate Ms Valente's talent and craftsmanship.WOW!Recommended: To those who like fairytales, fantasy and beautiful prose.Cover:: 5 stars ...more

author: Reed, Emma Leigh*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 2 starsI was given a copy of this book in exchange for my honest . So here it goes:This is the first ARC I've ever received. I read the blurb an2 starsI was given a copy of this book in exchange for my honest . So here it goes:This is the first ARC I've ever received. I read the blurb and I thought the novel sounded interesting. But, there were so many things that bugged me. The insta-lust/love between Kira and Grant, for one. The dialogues are contrived and very un-natural. I've known autistic kids for some time now. I didn't buy it for one second how Jared, Kira's 4-5 year old autistic son, was expressing himself. Not even neurotypical (normal) kids act and talk like that. Not to mention that autistic kids hate change, don't warm to strangers quickly, but somehow Jared is just besotted with Grant, and later with his family, because what? In many respects, given the dialogues between Jared and his mum or Grant's family, he sounded like a perfectly reasonable 10 year old not a pre-school kid, definitely not like a partially non-verbal kid, who mostly used sign language to communicate. It really irritated me how Grant went on and on about how Kira was such a wonderful mother, after meeting her a couple of times, not to mention telling her to relax etc. I've rolled my eyes numerous times. And after several meetings, not even dates, he confesses he loves her. They hadn't even had sex yet. There's also a lot of unnecessary dialogue, a lot of telling the readers how to feel instead of showing. And how was Kira, a stay-at-home mum, able to pay for a house-keeper? Now to mention why would she need her? That just didn't make sense. There's a lot of repetition going on, for example we are told several times what "sensory therapy" is. I got it the first time.The character development is lacking. I felt completely disconnected and disinterested in the characters. I couldn't even create an image in my head of their appearance.To end on a positive side: I didn't find any grammar mistakes and the punctuation was pretty good.Recommended: I do not recommend 2 star books. It was very well written, and I liked the few snippets of conversations from the Narcoleptics forum. Why a Narcoleptics' forum? Because the main character, Dominic Christy is one, and he's coming to turns with managing this sleeping disorder, with losing his beloved job as a traffic controller and also trying to get over a relationship break-up. He's living in with his cousin and family. Reluctantly, he takes on his counsin's suggestion to try alternative therapies. And so, he comes across the beautiful reflexologist, Liza Reece. He feels an instant attraction, but he's rudely refused when he asks her out to dinner. Their paths will cross again in this small village. And then, they become business competitors. Liza is fierce and stubborn and won't take any shit from men. And given her bad break-up,she swore off men. But she's very attracted to Dominic, who's not only handsome and smart, he seems to be around when she needs help. It was very interesting to get a greater insight into narcolepsy. I loved both main protagonists and the secondary ones. The story had a good plot, and everything that happened was plausible. A great contemporary romance read! review: 3 hyped starsI've read this book because I saw they were making it into a movie and I also noticed its ratings. From the very begging, this book sort 3 hyped starsI've read this book because I saw they were making it into a movie and I also noticed its ratings. From the very begging, this book sort of reminded me of that Julia Roberts movie "Dying Young". The book was very predictable, what "saved" it for me was that in the end (view spoiler)[ Will, the male protagonist, follows through with his decision to end his life  (hide spoiler)].Speaking of the heroine, I wasn't quite sure what to make of her. I didn't look down on her for not knowing what she wanted in/from life, because let's face it, many people go through that, at least sometimes. Sure, there was some self-deprecating humour and some sarcasm, but I thought that she was a bit of a doormat, although she kept stating (she's the narrator) that she was outspoken, which was completely contradicted by her actions: sticking with her boyfriend, who was totally incompatible with her; still living with her parents and extended family etc. Hey, but she had a very quirky way of dressing, as in very colourful, very out-there, which again, contradicts another of her statements that after a particular bad experience, which I won't mention, she decided to dress in a way so no one found her attractive, or something like that. Well, she was standing out and attracting attention. But that's not important, these were just some of the things that bugged me.Of course, the fact that she's completely unqualified to look after a quadriplegic, but yet she gets the job, based on a very short interview where she didn't do very well, it's another one of those yeah right moments. And Will, the quadriplegic male protagonist, is a grump, as he is well entitled to be. And eventually, he warms up to her, based on what... I can't quite remember... Anyway, they become close. Feelings develop. He pushes her out of her "comfort zone" to "live life" etc.... He tells her she can do more with her life! He tells her what she can become! And she does it because the man said it! Where would us women be without the men telling us what to do and showing us "the way"?And wouldn't you know it, there's a happy ending of sorts for the heroine. I gave this novel 3 stars because assisted suicide is an important issue worth talking about and definitely worth pondering about. ...more
