title: A Fraction of the Whole
author: Toltz, Steve
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I finally finished this 25-hour long audiobook. I am so glad I stuck with it, despite my recently acquired dislike of overly long novels.This novel waI finally finished this 25-hour long audiobook. I am so glad I stuck with it, despite my recently acquired dislike of overly long novels.This novel was shortlisted for the 2008 Man Booker prize, which in itself should have brought it more notoriety, especially in Australia. A Fraction of the Whole is a mammoth of a book, on another level. It's highly intelligent, original, funny and deep, philosophical, irreverent, and still so relevant. My husband happened to hear some passages and he asked if I was listening to a politician's memoir. On another occasion, he laughed out loud when hearing a character's musings. It's that kind of novel, that changes pace, direction, one moment is deep or mundane, the next it comes up with a funny observation or some sort of witticism. I'm impressed with Toltz's ability to maintain such a high level for over five hundred pages. I won't lie, at times, in the first half, I felt like I was being slapped over the head with the incessant philosophical meanderings of Martin Dean. But that was exactly who he was - a man prone to analysis, over-thinking, over-reading. Some of his observations were mindblowing and highly quotable.The main characters of this novel are the two brothers, Martin and Terry Dean, Martin's son, Jasper Dean. We mainly hear Martin and Jasper's point of views. They're fascinating and completely bonkers. A Fraction of the Whole is mainly about families, the ties the bound us, make or break us. Despite its imperfections, I feel compelled to give this five stars, because it's outstanding in so many ways....more

title: How to Be Good
author: Hornby, Nick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4.5 Incredibly introspective stars   Not recommended for those who are looking to escape This was the first Nick Hornby book I've ever read. I've seen4.5 Incredibly introspective stars   Not recommended for those who are looking to escape This was the first Nick Hornby book I've ever read. I've seen some of his films, and I enjoyed them a great deal! I thought this book was extraordinary!!! I would normally be quick to shout "what does a man know about a woman", "how dare he write in the first person, from a woman's point of view", but Hornby is spot on! He must be a very perceptive person. I loved the tone, the British sarcasm and wit of the liberal, middle class doctor, Katie Carr, who's trying to figure out how she's ended up in a loveless marriage, with an over-bearing, enraged husband, with kids who aren't too bad, but whom she sometimes doesn't like that much. Basically, she's having a mid-life crisis, where she doesn't know what's the point to anything, or if there is a point. She's having an affair, after twenty years in a monogamous relationship, but she's not very enthused or sees the point of that either.And then, things change. More exactly, her husband changes. There's a case of be careful what you wish for, when David, Katie's husband, becomes a very altruistic, mild, "save the world" type of person, who no longer finds everything and everyone aggravating and worth of his disdain. There is a case of better the devil you know, when Katie has to adapt to different changes, that take even more energy. There is a lot of doubt, some outbursts, confused kids thrown in the mix. Will Katie and David's marriage survive? Is surviving enough? But is giving up and walking away the answer? I suppose this book is not for everyone. While there are some funny moments, it's a very realistic, therefore dry and depressing account of a middle aged couple and their struggles. But it is extremely well written, it's very introspective and I suspect one could draw lots of conclusions from it. Great book, although depressing!...more

title: The Anonymous Blog of Mrs. Jones
author: Harger, Ellen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4 Soul-searching StarsThis novel was unlike many other books in the genre, I wouldn't even call it a romance book, because there's not much romancing 4 Soul-searching StarsThis novel was unlike many other books in the genre, I wouldn't even call it a romance book, because there's not much romancing going on. It's a truthful exploration of relationships, of changing without knowing, of just losing the spark and finding yourself in a place, both spiritual and physical, and not really knowing how you got there. What happened? Who am I? Who's this stranger I share my life with? Is that it? Lots and lots of questions. I am certain that many women will relate, or understand, or just draw some life lessons or just conclusions. Or maybe not. It sure made me introspective (not sure I wanted to go that way, but anyway... ;-) )Initially, I found the writing style quite terse. Simple and to the point, without many embellishments. But, it really suited our depressed heroine, Gillian. It suited her personality and her mood. But then, as she tries new things and starts writing her true feelings in a blog, the writing has a new, very different flow, and it becomes quite poetic. There is an unexpected twist in the story , which I thought was very interesting ( although I'd guessed it - *pats herself on the back :-)).Why I didn't give this book 5 stars:- I didn't connect enough with the characters, I looked from outside in. But in conclusion, this is a novel worth your time. In this overabundant market of women's novels, where many times you feel like you've read that book before, it's quite nice coming across something that's fresh and different. Recommended: To those who like realistic fiction;Cover: 4+ stars...more

author: Laqueur, Suanne*

review: 5 stars of AwesomenessSuanne Laquer’s first book “The Man I Love” was such a tremendous novel, I was thrilled to hear she was working on another one. 5 stars of AwesomenessSuanne Laquer’s first book “The Man I Love” was such a tremendous novel, I was thrilled to hear she was working on another one. My excitement and impatience made me ask the author if she’d give me an ARC, and incredibly enough, she sent me one! So here's the disclaimer: I received this ARC for an honest .I am not a writer, so I’m afraid my attempt at writing a  won’t be able to convey how truly wonderful this novel is. I know it doesn’t sound very elegant, but I practically inhaled Give Me Your Answer True. I resented the everyday stuff that stopped me from reading it. I remember having a similar experience when I was reading The Man I Love.But that’s the thing about Suanne Laquer’s writing. She draws you in. You breathe and feel one with the characters. With all of them. Because all the characters in the book have so much depth, it’s uncanny. Erik Fiskare, whose voice we heard in The Man I Love, is just amazing! He is my new book dream man! Daisy Bianco, his love interest and the narrator in Give Me Your Answer True, is beautiful inside and out. And although she’s a fragile ballerina, she’s incredibly strong.(view spoiler)[But she’s hurting. Badly! Life was good. Her 3 year relationship with Erik was stronger and more passionate than ever. Their friends and roommates, Will and Lucky, were happy. But then life throws them a big bad one! Everybody changes. Moving on is not so easy. The hurt and the nightmares are just too much to deal with. Then Daisy does a bad thing. A mistake that will break Erik’s heart.All Daisy’s got left is the ballet. Will she be able to get over the heartbreak and depression? Will she forgive herself? Will Erik forgive her?  (hide spoiler)]Give Me Your Answer True is about Daisy’s journey for over 12 years. We fall in love with Erik, like she did. And then we’re travelling alongside Daisy for many years, while she’s working hard at forgiving herself, at moving on, at trying to be without Erik. Her pain and despair are almost palpable. Good writing will make you feel, and Suanne Laquer accomplishes this feat beautifully.There are no clichés. It’s all very realistic, without being banal. The book has a wonderful flow, and several story telling techniques are in play, including letters. Even the sex scenes are well written, they’re not too detailed, but not too generic either. They’re not gratuitous and thrown in there for cheap titillations. It’s not about mechanics, it’s about feeling and feelings.I thought the ballet/stage world added an extra dimension to the story. I also loved that Suanne Laquer (re)introduced me to new or some forgotten beautiful pieces of music. Whenever the name of a song or classical piece was mentioned, I’d go online and listen to it. It made the whole experience (even) more enjoyable.Given how much I adored The Man I Love, I had some trepidations about reading the same story from a different perspective, especially since I had been disappointed by other authors’ attempts. But Suanne Laquer manages the almost impossible – improving on something wonderful! I didn’t think that was possible, but she did it! And it didn’t matter one bit that I already knew the story.I truly enjoyed getting to know the secondary characters a bit better. Suanne Laquer is such a splendid writer, she manages to infuse realism and passion into all her characters. So, if you’re looking for something beautifully written, that’s realistic and passionate, than, welcome, you’ve arrived. Recommended: Absolutely! To anyone who enjoys beautifully written prose, with wonderful characters and a realistic plot.Cover: 5 stars...more

The main female character, Auden, is still trying to come to terms with her academic parents' divorce. She feels she's at fault for not keeping them together. Auden can't sleep at night. Over the summer she decides to go spend the summer with her dad and his new wife and their new baby girl. There she meets, Eli, who's unable to sleep at night, just like Auden. Their life experiences are different, but they connect on different levels. Eli makes Auden want to experience whatever she missed during her highschool years, where all she did was study and have high academic achievements. Over the summer spent in the little town by the ocean, Auden discovers there's more to herself, more to life than just burying yourself in books. ...more

title: Dirt Music
author: Winton, Tim
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this many years ago. While I knew I enjoyed it, I couldn't remember that much about it, which is very frustrating, but it's happened before andI read this many years ago. While I knew I enjoyed it, I couldn't remember that much about it, which is very frustrating, but it's happened before and it'll probably get worse. As I professed a million times before, Tim Winton is one of my favourite writers. His autographed books are some of my most treasured belongings. I was fortunate enough to see and hear him speak and have my books autographed on several occasions. My second taste of Dirt Music was via the e-audiobook. I didn't quite like the narrator and her delivery, but I persevered and finished it in record time. Things came back to me, especially certain details. Dirt Music is a quintessential Winton novel, in that the landscape, mostly the Western Australian coast, plays a big role in the characters' lives. Forty-year-old Georgie Jutland has been married for three years to the prosperous fisherman, Jim Buckridge. They live in White Point, a fictional coastal town. Luther Fox is thirty-five, lives off the grid and, occasionally, helps himself to crayfish and other sea creatures, despite not having a fishing license. Georgie feels restless and unsettled. She doesn't sleep much and she may have a bit of a drinking problem. Circumstances bring her and Luth together and an affair begins, so the big troubles start, especially since Luther Fox was already a persona non-grata in the community.I found the characters and their conduct irritating and odd at times. Some had more reasons than others to feel depressed, down on their luck, lost and self-destructive.But then it's only an illusion that people are logical or that they act rationally all the time.The last part was a bit unbelievable, it even had a dose of soap-opera to it, at least, that's how I perceived it this time around.Nevertheless, it was a satisfying read, even though I wasn't completely under its spell.So, I'm downgrading this to 4 stars....more

title: Cloudstreet
author: Winton, Tim
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Cloudstreet was the first Winton novel I read. At the time, I had lived in Perth for less than two years, I was still discovering the city. For those Cloudstreet was the first Winton novel I read. At the time, I had lived in Perth for less than two years, I was still discovering the city. For those outside Australia, Perth is the capital of Western Australia (WA), one of the most isolated capital cities in the world. The better known Sydney and Melbourne are "only" 4, 5 hrs away by plane. Those huge cities are where things are happening. Most publishers are located in one of those two cities. If I'm not mistaken, Winton is one of the first WA writers to make it big in Australia. Cloudstreet won the Miles Franklin Award, one of the most prestigious literary awards in Australia. Of course, that's not why I adore him, I don't do patriotism, I don't necessarily think that being from a place or another makes one better or worse, even though geography does impact one's views, opportunities etc. It's nice to read about a place you know personally. Long story short, Tim Winton is the best promoter of WA and isn't it wonderful that it's via culture - not via our usual primary industry exports.Anyway, it was wonderful to (re)visit with the Pickles and the Lambs, in their huge, rundown mansion on Cloudstreet, Perth over a twenty-year period (1943 - 63). I rediscovered some of the details and nuances that time had blurred away. It was an enjoyable reading experience just like the first time around....more

title: The Man I Love        (The Fish Tales, #1)
author: Laqueur, Suanne*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 5 dancing starsFinally, a book that has very high ratings and didn't disappoint. I probably won't be able to articulate very well how good this book  5 dancing starsFinally, a book that has very high ratings and didn't disappoint. I probably won't be able to articulate very well how good this book was, because I haven't fully de-constructed what made it so fantastic.The main characters of the book, Erik Fiskare and Daisy Bianco are very likable and incredibly well written.The writing style is quite unique, in that it had a staccato rhythm to it, moving through Erik's childhood and teenage years and then expanding through the college years. The book is written in the third person (a rarity these days) and we're witnesses to Erik's story. Erik and Daisy's love for each other is complete and all consuming. They are the perfect match up of two souls and bodies. The yin and yang, the soulmates. One day tragedy strikes. Erik and Daisy are affected deeply by the tragedy. They try hard to move on, but it's not easy, things are never the same. Then the inevitable happens, the melt down and (view spoiler)[ the break up. Erik can't forgive and feels completely lost, depressed, and anxious. He cuts any links with all his university friends, who had actually become his family. He just can't forget and forgive. Not being able to cope, he finally sees a psychologist and for a long time they dig and dig. Eventually, Erik gets married. But things don't work out, because he was still not over Daisy.  (hide spoiler)].This was a long book, it's dense and wordy, but it's beautiful and compelling! It's impossible not to love Erik and Daisy. It's worth saying that the secondary characters, Will and Dave, Lucky and others are very well written as well. It is a book about love, growing up, trauma, recovery, forgiveness, second chances. It is passionate, intelligent, emotional and raw! A truly incredible book! A favourite!  Recommended: To anyone who appreciates a well written novel, with amazing characters and realistic plot. Also, if you love the ballet and the stage, this is the book for you! Cover: 5 stars...more

title: Capture        (Elements of Chemistry, #3; Hypothesis, #1.3)
author: Reid, Penny*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 5 starsThe release of Capture on Mothers' Day was the perfect present! Thank you, Penny! I was so frustrated about having to wait to find out what ha 5 starsThe release of Capture on Mothers' Day was the perfect present! Thank you, Penny! I was so frustrated about having to wait to find out what happens next ... Of course, once I realised my pre-order was ready for download, I quickly stopped what I was doing and started reading. And I had to finish it in one sitting, so now I'm tired and grumpy as I didn't get much sleep last night, but I'm also happy I've finished the novel. I have to say that while I thought Kaitlyn was magnificently awesome, I wasn't a big fan of Martin, as I wasn't that keen on his entitled, domineering personality, but his interest in Kaitlyn sure redeemed him somewhat.But in Capture, he becomes (almost) a new man, a better man, which let's face it, it doesn't happen in reality, but I guess that's why we read these books. What is it they say: women dream men will change, and men hope that women never will? :-) But Kaitlyn changes a bit as well, she becomes less sheltered and makes important decisions based on what's good for her and not on what everyone expects of her. In the process, she becomes happier and more self assured and she's got Martin's bluntness to thank for that. So yes, this was the perfect love story, where two perfectly imperfect people come together, and by being together they become the best versions of themselves. Big sigh... Thank you, Penny Reid for yet another wonderful love story. But PLEAAASSEEE no more books split in 2-3 volumes! With all due respect, I hate this practice! I understand the marketing/financial reasoning for it, but still, I am not a big fan! I don't even like it in movies, but it could also be because most movies that have 2, 3, 4 after them are ludicrous and hurt my intelligence (I noticed the Europeans and other non-Hollywood film makers never indulge in the practice). So, to conclude my /drivel: I love Penny Reid's writing style and the female characters she creates so much, I even endured the excruciating wait for each volume to be released. Also, Kaitlyn is now officially my favourite female character of all Penny Reid books!!! I can't wait for the next Penny Reid novel! Recommended:: To everyone who enjoys reading books with strong, quirky female characters. Cover: 5 stars ...more

review: 3 - 3.5 Difficult Love StarsI'm not quite sure how to rate this book. I liked that it showed a relationship that you don't see it described often, tha3 - 3.5 Difficult Love StarsI'm not quite sure how to rate this book. I liked that it showed a relationship that you don't see it described often, that between an older woman and a younger man. In a way, despite the age difference, both Caroline and Sebastian were much closer in age, as they were both lonely, insecure and just drifting along. This relationship was very effervescent. The forbidden relationship is exciting, obsessive and the consequences of being caught are far too drastic. It's hard to blame Caroline for falling for Sebastian. She's not predatory, if anything, Sebastian is the pursuer. The relationship is very intense. And there's a lot of sex. Lots and lots of sex. Also, the book is very dense, at times too detailed. While everything is happening in a very short period of time, 6-8 weeks(?), at times it felt like many months had passed. To be honest, I found myself rolling my eyes and wanting to slap Caroline for the unnecessary risks taken. And yeah, I dislike cliffhangers, even though I bought the book as a package, so now I'm reading the follow up - the Education of Caroline.It's not my favourite Jane Harvey-Berrick book, but it's still a good book, well written, with great insight into the characters....more

title: The Marriage Trap        (Marriage to a Billionaire, #2)
author: Probst, Jennifer*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 2.5 Spanitalian StarsFirst and foremost, I'll have to address something that really, really, really bugged me: the author's confusion/ignorance of It 2.5 Spanitalian StarsFirst and foremost, I'll have to address something that really, really, really bugged me: the author's confusion/ignorance of Italian with/and Spanish. For example: at 72% the author uses "loco" which is Spanish for crazy, the Italian is "pazzo". 73% "Mia amore" is incorrect! It should have been "amore mio". The male character, Italian millionaire, Michael - such an Italian name - NOT, uses the word "dios" again and again. WRONG! That's Spanish for "god". The Italian is "Dio". Also, "bambinos" at 91% is Spanish for children/babies, in Italian they call them "bambini". I find it inexcusable that the author and/or the editor(s) could not be bothered to do a simple Google search. That just annoys the hell out of me. Since I'm on the language bandwagon, I found it very incredulous that Michael's entire family was so perfectly fluent in English, even his mum and the priest, and the nephews. If one visits Italy, one will discover that the majority of the Italians are not fluent in English, you're lucky if they speak any English at all. Besides the language issues, the book was all right. That is if you don't mind the clichés, and the marrying to fool the family thing, that's been done to death in romance books. So while I was reading this book, I had lots of "yeah right", "WTF" and eye rolling. The male and female characters were Ok, but we've met them before in other similar books. ...more

review: I wasn't in any particular hurry to read the third instalment of the Winston Brothers series, as the first two were somewhat blah. But I was at my locI wasn't in any particular hurry to read the third instalment of the Winston Brothers series, as the first two were somewhat blah. But I was at my local library and incredibly enough they had lots of Penny Reid novels, including this new release, so I borrowed it.I'm glad I did, as this was so much more enjoyable than the previous two novels. Arguably, Cletus despite the horrible name, is the most interesting brother. He's intelligent, extremely resourceful and doesn't mix his words. Jennifer Sylvester is very young and inexperienced. She's the Banana Cake Queen. An amazing baker, under her parents' thumbs. She's lonely and doesn't have any friends. She knows people are laughing at her behind her back. She looks ridiculous with her fake eyelashes and heavy make-up, yellow housedresses, and bleached hair. When she inadvertently films Cletus Winston doing something he shouldn't have, she decides to blackmail him into finding her a husband. You can probably imagine what happens next. By far, this has been my favourite (stand-alone) novel in the series. I didn't have as many grumblings if any. I was ready to give up on the Winston Brothers series, but after reading Beard Science, I'm reconsidering....more

title: Grin and Beard It        (Winston Brothers, #2)
author: Reid, Penny*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 starsI enjoyed "Grin and Beard It" more than the first novel in the Winston Brothers series. But only marginally. I wasn't dissatisfied with the c3.5 starsI enjoyed "Grin and Beard It" more than the first novel in the Winston Brothers series. But only marginally. I wasn't dissatisfied with the characters, the plot or the dialogue, as I remember being the case with "Truth and Beard It". Our main protagonists are as different as they can be: Sienna Diaz is the A-list, Latina, Oscar-winning Hollywood actress. Jethro Winston - again, the name, grrr, but I already knew what his name was going to be so I should just chill about the names - is a park ranger and a former bad-boy, who's now has changed his ways. Jethro is a smooth operator, and so is Sienna. Their attraction is reciprocal and instant. Sienna loves that Jethro seems to be the only person in the world who doesn't know who she is. As per the well-established romance formula, misunderstandings and some angst ensue. I did notice that there was no slut shaming (Yay!), and I did like the feminist stand and the discussions over minority issues, the female body perception and the pressure to look a certain way. But even these issues that tickle my fancy big time were not enough to make me love the novel. The internal monologue was a bit too much, I felt we were told way too much, and given that it had alternate, first person POV's, we were told pretty much everything. It could have been my foul mood (reason for my decision to read this novel, so that I can relax), but the novel felt flat and I didn't quite get the spark.Looking forward to seeing what Cletus' story will be like. He sounds intriguing.  Cover: 5 stars...more

review: 2 lukewarm stars Another book that was a huge disappointment, especially given the average 4.3 stars.Not only is the writing average, contrite, lacki 2 lukewarm stars Another book that was a huge disappointment, especially given the average 4.3 stars.Not only is the writing average, contrite, lacking good syntax, the plot is so full of clichés, so uneventful and even the sex scenes were really unimaginative and not sexy at all, despite the author's poor attempts at building excitement by postponing the unavoidable sex scenes until the 80% of the book. Remington St Germain was supposed to be sexy and mysterious etc, but in my opinion, the only thing sexy about him was his name. Although the book is very short, there are several things that just don't add up: 1. Selene is 26 years old. In the prologue she says she's been married for 6 years. Then, when talking to Remington, she tells him not only that she got married at 21 (21+6 = 27) but she says she's been divorced for 2 years. What the? Simple math, dear Autumn Grey, simple math. 2. There is no way that she couldn't have found a hotel room in Paris, the city that has over 17,000 hotels.3. The fact that Selene ends up spending the night in Remington's house is really over the top and unbelievable. Not only that, it turns out the dude owned a boutique hotel. 4. She meets his son in the morning after her first night staying at Remi's house, who was supposed to be away anyway. Not only that, the little boy, takes instant like to her and compliments her on her beauty and then asks his father if she can stay with them, because we all know that's what little boys do .The writing and dialogues are preposterous. Here's an example:"My drumstick-filled hand halted at my mouth. 'Why? What did he tell you?' He laughed: 'I've known him for five years. I've seen him treat his women with respect, literally laying his money at their feet to make sure they were happy' ( wow, imagine that, he was pasting banknotes in front of those women, because that's what literally laying his money at their feet means. "However, allocating one of his precious expensive suites for any of them in his hotel? I never thought I'd see the day".  Why is a hotel room so precious, especially since he was "literally laying his money"? You get the drift.So in conclusion:- the writing is bad- the plot is over-the-top- the protagonists are bland- the sex scenes lukewarm______________________________________ONE AVERAGE BOOK, even for the genre. review: I'll have to start this  with a disclaimer: I love Penny Reid's novels, I've read all of them. Unfortunately, this novel didn't really do it forI'll have to start this  with a disclaimer: I love Penny Reid's novels, I've read all of them. Unfortunately, this novel didn't really do it for me. Were my expectations too high? Possibly.I've come to expect interesting characters, and I'm afraid, I didn't think much about our protagonists.Jessica James is a 22 year-old high school math teacher. She's also the daughter of the local sheriff and her brother is his deputy. And that's about all there is to say about Jessica. There were no witty comments or observations, no funny episodes. I thought she was plain and uninteresting. She sounded and acted like a teenager. And she was a bit of a horndogbitch(?)(not sure what's the female for horndog).As for the male protagonist, Duane, it was difficult to get over my dislike for his name. I like names. I think they're important. And Duane was too redneck-y for my liking. So were his other brothers' names. But I digress. I liked Duane more than Jessica. He's a 24, an auto-mechanic, part owner of an auto-repair business. He's a red-blooded young man, who's had a crush on Jessica for years. While Jessica is all over him, he won't take things too far because he "respects" her and wants a future with her. So let me get this right: fingering and oral sex is fine, but having intercourse is not "respectful"? I don't get it. I've recently come across this in several books, most of them new adult romance novels. It must be a new thing, or it could be just me not getting the younger generations. Or could be the fact that I'm not American. But yeah, I find all these concepts perplexing. And no, I'm no prude. I'll stop my rant.I'm trying to articulate why I didn't gel with this novel. Could it have something to do with the setting? Possibly. More than likely it's because I didn't care much about the two protagonists. Jessica was too two-dimensional and was acting like a silly teenager. Duane sounded too articulate, too well-read (I know, I know his momma made him read), too level-headed and grown up for a 24 year old and I just didn't buy it, although those are attributes I like in a guy, unlike all the other hillbilly characteristics. The only brother who piqued my interest was Cletus (although, the name... grr). I'd like to know more about him. It looks like we'll have to wait for the third book in the series to read his story. As for the plot, it didn't really do it for me either. It felt contrived, at times too convenient, and I had a few quibbles here and there, but I won't go into them because of spoilers.So, in conclusion, was this novel terrible? Certainly not. Will I be reading the next one in the series? I sure will. Cover: 5 stars...more

review: 2.5 Not Such a Savant Stars I had mixed feelings about this book. I should have liked it a lot, given that the male protagonist is supposed to be a ve2.5 Not Such a Savant Stars I had mixed feelings about this book. I should have liked it a lot, given that the male protagonist is supposed to be a very intelligent man (a big turn on for me). But I didn't buy it. Ford, a 26 yo rich, handsome and with an Aspergers diagnosis (for those unaware, that's a form of high functioning autism), keeps telling us that he doesn't care about anyone, and that he can't feel like most normal people do (relatively true for most people on the autism spectrum) etc. but man, his internal monologues, empathy, considerate behaviour are over the top, even for a neuro-typical man. Many things didn't quite feel right: Ford is only 26 yo and he has had a lot of work experience producing TV shows - how many people in their early 20s are producers? And the fact that a person with Aspergers syndrome would go for an arty degree (without being a prodigy) when he was supposed to be a savant, it's hard to believe. OK, I know, nobody gives a rats about these details, that's not why we read this kind of books. Unfortunately for me, I do pick up on such details. Both Ford and Ashleigh were apparently very educated, but they could have been farmers or high-school drop outs, their dialogues didn't seem too intelligent to me. I also thought that Ashleigh, a single mum of a 3 months old baby, who was both emotionally and physically drained, was over the top horny. I know, it's fiction, but still... Speaking of babies, that baby was the most sleepy baby ever!!!! How convenient! The story drags at times, and I found the first person narrative very annoying, as I stated in other s. Also, some editing is needed. So anyway, in conclusion: is this the worst book I've read? NO. Is it 5 stars? Absolutely NOT! ...more

title: All the Light We Cannot See
author: Doerr, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ending the year on a high note!Can a novel published only a year ago become a classic? All the Light We Cannot See sure has that “feel", quality aboutEnding the year on a high note!Can a novel published only a year ago become a classic? All the Light We Cannot See sure has that “feel", quality about it. I also think this would make a great book to be studied in high-school or college/university.I'm only going to jot down a few things, as there are so many wonderful s on Goodreads.There were so many things I loved about All the Light We Cannot See. This novel is so layered, so thorough and is also very touching without being sappy. The writing, while relatively simple, is exquisite. I loved the third person narrative and I didn't mind at all the alternate POVs or the very quirky, small chapters that were popping here and there. This novel is so high on details, it’s hard not to imagine yourself on the streets of Paris, or walking through the Natural History Museum, or strolling the streets of the quaint, seaside town of Saint-Malo.The descriptions were extremely vivid. At times, I felt as if I was suffering from synaesthesia – where senses get somewhat amalgamated and mixed up – you associate colour to numbers or smells to touching certain textures. Beautifully olfactory as times, Doerr manages to make us “see” what Marie-Laure was “seeing”. The character development is absolutely exquisite. You’ll be hard pressed not to love the two young protagonists – Marie – Laure, who’s a blind French girl, and Werner Pfennig– a German orphan, who ends up becoming a soldier in the German army, despite not being of age. Their innocence is taken by the war. They’re thrown into situations none of them would have ever imagined. The love and dedication of Marie-Laure’s father were quite touching. He was an intelligent man, a dotting single father, who was trying to make his blind daughter’s life as easy as possible. One of the things he comes up with is a miniature town that he painstakingly builds so that she can learn her way around their neighbourhood. I also enjoyed, or better said, appreciated Doerr’s take on the Nazis. By telling us about Werner’s history as a little boy, Werner enrolled in an elite school, Werner’s struggles during the war, Doerr humanised him, so he no longer was just a Nazi. Most books on the subject, vilify, make unredeemable monsters of all the Germans. Surely, they were not all bad. What they did as a collective was atrocious! But, most people, taken as individuals, are quite decent beings. Only when put together with others, that’s when things change. It’s an interesting, somewhat puzzling characteristic of human behaviour, that makes otherwise decent people act/behave like … I won’t say animals, as that would be derogatory towards the animals. Just watch young men (and not only) together on a night in town. Then add the will to conform and belong, circumstances, propaganda, patriotism, fear, youth and a few other things, and you’ve got yourself a group of monsters.I loved how music, and science, and reading sort of connected two people that were supposed to be enemies. Anyway, I’ll end this  by saying All The Light We Cannot See is deserving of all the accolades. I’m glad I got to read it. This is one of those books that begs to be re-read. I’ve received this novel via NetGalley. Many thanks to HarperCollins UK, HarperPress/4th Estate/The Friday Project for allowing me to read and  this tremendous novel. Cover: 5 stars...more

She's 4 stars of quirkiness This novella was short, sweet and funny. The female protagonist, Lucy, is a genius, doing her PhD at the young age of 20. She's probably got Aspergers - a high functioning form of autism - although it's never mentioned in the book. She's socially inept, she doesn't have any friends, and doesn't know much about emotions, experiencing emotions. But when her grant to study emotion as a pathogen is under threat of being removed, she's forced to start making friends, to try to find out about emotions, about what makes people tick, about lust and sexual desire. Suddenly she notices her hunky neighbour, Jensen, who's a pre-law student and who has the reputation of a playboy. He's beginning to help her with her "experiment/project". Throw some over bearing parents in the mix and some misunderstandings and you've got the perfect recipe for disaster. But love conquers all. review: How do I rate this book? In the beginning, I thought it was so cute, I loved the smart comments, the fast pace and the tongue-in-cheek observations. WHow do I rate this book? In the beginning, I thought it was so cute, I loved the smart comments, the fast pace and the tongue-in-cheek observations. While all the young adult novels are very predictable, I thought that the dialogues felt very "young adult", and I was really enjoying the ride. But about 1/3 through the book, or maybe half way through, things started to decline for me. I found myself noticing things that didn't quite add up or that annoyed me: how would a 15 yo know so much about music? Ok, she's been home schooled for many years and had more free time, but how would a teenage boy, busy with sports and hooking up and being in school for most of the day, have had time to acquire so much knowledge about classic movies and music? Anyway, no biggie. One of the things that annoyed me, and it seems to be a constant, especially with the young adult genre, is when other girls are referred to as sluts. How Camie took an instant dislike to Teresa and became so nasty towards her after finding out that she was interested in the male protagonist - I found that disconcerting. Especially since she was supposed to be such a "goody two shoes", and god fearing blah blah... It's interesting to note that things hadn't changed a whole lot from when I was in highschool, especially about the double standards when it comes to girls. But the authors are grown ups, who should know better, what's up with this? Can't we get over calling other women sluts, tramps, while brushing off guys' behaviour? Speaking of Camie, she moved pretty quickly from never have been kissed to allowing Tristan unhook her bra, put his hands on her naked butt etc. Anyway, these are just few of the things that were bugging me. There isn't much going on in this book. There's a whole lot of dialogue, analysis of each and every glance, blink, body posture, clothes etc. ... I found myself skipping paragraphs as I was getting bored. So, let's just say that my initial excitement about the book quickly dwindled. And no, I will not be reading the other 2 books (Why???) in the series - which is another pet hate of mine of how authors these days make three books when one - well written and edited novel - would have sufficed! You know the old adage "quality over quantity"? It's mostly missing these days. ...more

review: 1 unfulfilled stars  DNF34% into this book and I just had to give up as I was getting annoyed. Really, I should have stopped reading earlier, but I w 1 unfulfilled stars  DNF34% into this book and I just had to give up as I was getting annoyed. Really, I should have stopped reading earlier, but I was distracted watching TV while reading. First of all about the writing: it's bad! Besides the annoying 1st person narrative, the dialogues are irritating and unrealistic and the syntax is all over the place.The characters are clichéd and uninteresting, with the goody-two-shoes Scarlett being just... so uninteresting. And of course , two drop-dead gorgeous guys happen to instantly fall for her, because you know, she was the only good looking girl out there (yep, I'm being sarcastic). And for someone who's a virgin, she sure starts "sucking face" with a guy at her first ever party, after just meeting him. When she gets back to where she was staying, Ash, the other hot guy, invites her to go to his bedroom, and she agrees? What the? The irony was not lost on me, that at the party, she was referring to the two girls hanging with Ash as bimbos, although they were doing so much less than what she was about to do later in his bedroom.One of my biggest gripes with the romance genre, especially with the young adult/new adult sub-genre is the slut shaming. Authors, please stop slut shaming!!! Scarlett apparently was a "book whore" (I didn't know there was such a thing), because she read lots and lots of romance novels. It's interesting that her controlling parents didn't have much to say about what she was reading. Thank goodness I haven't yet gotten around to reading any sex scenes. Something tells me they were multi-orgasmic, just like in real life. ;-)...more

review: Ha! I seem to be expanding my (reading) horizons unwillingly. I saw the title on Amazon, and that it was a Tiffany Reisz book so I 1-clicked it. I didHa! I seem to be expanding my (reading) horizons unwillingly. I saw the title on Amazon, and that it was a Tiffany Reisz book so I 1-clicked it. I didn't read the blurb, because I'm adventurous like that (*insert sarcasm), so sometimes I like to be surprised. So now apparently I've dipped my toes into the fantasy-paranormal genre. I've read quite a few books by Ms Reisz to know that she writes well. This was a pleasant, quick read, about Edwin Yorke, a good looking 40 year old British headmaster at an all-boy highschool, and the 25 year old Gwen Ashby, who's looking for a teaching job. She ends up at the William Marshall Academy and gets a week trial teaching literature. She's instantly intrigued and fascinated with the proper Mr Yorke. She also finds him extremely attractive. I won't say much more about this book, because of fear of spoiling it for you.I will say though that it's competently written, enjoyable and like all Tiffany Reisz stories, it's full of passion. I've never listened to an audio book, but I think I would have enjoyed listening to the Headmaster, had the Edwin Yorke character been voiced by someone with a proper, posh English accent (that accent does things to me ;-))Recommended:/ To Tiffany Reisz's fans and everyone who enjoys a sweet paranormal romance.Cover: 4 stars...more

author: Cosway, L.H.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the first e-book I've ever pre-ordered, as I was very keen to get my hands on something new by L.H. Cosway and Penny Reid, who recently have bThis is the first e-book I've ever pre-ordered, as I was very keen to get my hands on something new by L.H. Cosway and Penny Reid, who recently have become my favourite contemporary romance authors.So I got the book onto the kindle yesterday and finished it today. As with the other books written by the two lovely authors, it was hard to put down. The book is so contemporary, so vibrant and funny, you just want to read it all in one go, to see what happens next.It is the story of an Irish rugby player, Ronan, who is hiding in New York because of a scandal in his native Ireland. And amazingly enough, not only is he well built and gorgeous (looking like Colin Farrell), he's smart and well educated. I didn't think such a thing as an intelligent rugby player existed ;-)The female protagonist, Annie, is a socially inept hermit, who's working for a PR agency, as social media expert. Also she writes a very successful social/entertainment blog, under the pseudonym Socialmedialite. She's extremely intelligent and well educated, also beautiful, although she's trying her best to go by unnoticed by wearing unflattering clothes. As you can guess, Ronan and Annie get together. There are secrets. There is pushing and pulling. There is social pressure and work pressure. There is angst, and fear, and anger, and love. You've got it all in this book. I admire how the authors come up with such interesting characters, who have interesting jobs and tumultuous background history, but it is all believable, it's not all gratuitous soap-opera dramas like in many romance books. I loved coming across some of the Irish vernacular, although I would have liked more of that Irishness (new word ;-) to transpire. Thank goodness he wasn't the stereotypical happy drunk, or worse, happy Catholic drunk. Sooorrrrry The sex scenes were Caliente!!! I mean HOT! and somewhat different! So kudos to the authors for making that part interesting as well. The only problem I had was that the book finished. :-( Sometimes I really hate that I'm such a fast reader. So I'm really looking forward to reading the next releases: "Elements of Chemistry" by Penny Reid and "Hearts of Fire" by L.H. Cosway. 4.5 Stars...more

review: 2 and 1/2 starsThe book started pretty well, I was engaged. While the premise was predictable - good looking, bad boy falls for the nice, shy, virgin 2 and 1/2 starsThe book started pretty well, I was engaged. While the premise was predictable - good looking, bad boy falls for the nice, shy, virgin girl - I didn't mind it too much. (view spoiler)[ Elle, the female protagonist, showed a bit of personality once Nero, the main dude, started showing interest in her. But that didn't last long. Which I guess makes more sense, since she had been viciously bullied for years, including broken bones and cut hair. I know, hard to believe that would happen in a private, upper-class high-school. There were quite a few things that didn't sit well with me: first of all: the good girl witnesses a man being murdered, so what does she do? She rans home and tells no one about it. Say what??? Nero is "of course" good looking, well built, with girls at his little finger, you know, the usual cliché in this kind of books. I didn't like him. He was overbearing, sort of abusive and always shoving her around and telling her what to do. Kind of a bully. Elle always gave in and did what she was told which I guess, in a way, would fit with her victim personality prior to Nero, but I found it disappointing and boring. Her devotion to her best friend - Chloe - was over the top. I needed more of a background, history to accept it. Elle's parents - apparently nice people - were completely oblivious to Elle's suffering. The ending was a total let down: with basically Nero more of less forcing her to move in with him into an apartment into his fathers casino/hotel. And his father and entire family are the big Mafia family in the city. Ah, and Nero forces her to go to University in the town, although she had been accepted to Standaford, where she was going to go with her best friend,for whom she sacrificed so much, but who suddenly was forgotten... So yeah, lots of things didn't add up and that annoyed me. (hide spoiler)]The writing wasn't the worst I've seen around, but yeah, the ingredients weren't quite right. ...more

review: A very under-average novel. The characters were bland, and lots of things were incredulous: how Izzy, the main female character, changed her personaliA very under-average novel. Ah, and the petite woman can drink so much, a big-assed macho man would get alcohol poisoning, but not our heroine, she doesn't even get sick. The plot was drawn out and unrealistic. I didn't buy and will never buy that Greg, a young, healthy, testosterone filled male, who's not gay, will just hang around two young, beautiful women and be their guardian, without ever making a pass at either of them. Right!!!! As if that will ever happen! I didn't buy the drama about Izzy and Axel just losing track of each other. She didn't change her name, she went to University, she got married, there is no way he couldn't have tracked her down. Sure, when one reads this kind of books, one suspends their brain to a certain degree, but still... Ah, and I'm no prude but I didn't like Axel's sex talk, including his use of the C word. review: 2.5 over-rated starsI managed to finish this book, but it took a lot of effort as I didn't enjoy anything about it: the characters were badly written,2.5 over-rated starsI managed to finish this book, but it took a lot of effort as I didn't enjoy anything about it: the characters were badly written, uncharismatic, and very sketchy. Besides the dreaded 1st person narrative, the book had a poorly structured plot, and it was badly written and edited. I lost count of the many times I've rolled my eyes and said "yeah right" to myself. Things just didn't add up or were unlikely. It felt like I was reading a conglomerate of bits and pieces from other romance novels. Cami - the heroine - must have had more hours in the day than most people: she was working at a bar till early in the morning, than working at a tattoo parlour, while also attending University - which barely features in the book. The macho, alpha, tattooed male protagonist (Why do all the alpha males in the romance novels have to have tattooes?) - Trent - apparently had been in love with Cami since secondary school, but he never had the guts to approach her. Say what? Wasn't he the macho, confident, very desirable guy? It just didn't make sense. Cami's family issues was contrived and and inserted to create some drama, but it just did nothing. There were so many things that annoyed me. All I can think is thank goodness I didn't pay money for the book - somebody lent it to me. It cost $10+. I don't get how book prices are set, but I've read free romance novels with better plots and characters. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4 starsIt's a well-known reality that sequels usually disappoint. So I was a bit of apprehensive about reading this new Don Tillman novel, as I loved 4 starsIt's a well-known reality that sequels usually disappoint. So I was a bit of apprehensive about reading this new Don Tillman novel, as I loved the Rosie Project. But quite early into the book, I knew that I was going to enjoy it, all I had to do was find out whether it'll be a five-star book, as the Rosie Project was.Professor Don Tillman is now married and living in New York with his lovely wife, Rosie. Life is relatively comfortable and they've settled in NY pretty well. But Rosie's unplanned pregnancy shakes Don's organised life. Will he able to be a good father? As with everything else, he's trying to be logical and methodical about it, so he embarks on a study project of sorts in order to prepare and establish himself as a suitable father. But Don's social ineptness causes misunderstandings and all sorts of grief, although his intentions are always so honourable.This wasn't as good as the Rosie Project, but nevertheless, it was very enjoyable. Although this is written in the first person, (not a favourite of mine) it's perfectly suited for this novel, as it was for the Rosie Project. Don's way of trying to make sense of situations is so endearing. Or it was to me. The guy is completely innocent and he doesn't have a mean bone in his body. And he tries to help everyone around him. I thought he was very charming.Graeme Simsion has created a wonderful character in Don Tillman and the secondary characters are very well written as well. I quite like the writing style and the rhythm of both novels, they're quite unique, or at least I haven't come across other similar books. Not a five-star book for me, but still tremendously enjoyable.Recommended: Absolutely. Cover: 5 stars...more

review: My second read of this novel, this time in English, twenty-two years later.I had some trepidations getting into it. It's amazing that some images, litMy second read of this novel, this time in English, twenty-two years later.I had some trepidations getting into it. It's amazing that some images, little details stayed with me all this time. Of course, there were things I'd forgotten, such as the fact that Caravaggio was Hana's family friend, that Almasy, aka the English Patient, was fifteen years older than his love interest, Katherine. I confess, the movie adaptation, which I love, did muddle my reading experience a bit, albeit not as much as I expected it.If I were to put my super critical hat on, I'd say that all the details about the different kinds of bombs and how to dismantle them could have been cut, and the ending it was, arguably, unnecessary. Nevertheless, I loved re-reading this wonderful novel. Now I feel like watching the movie adaptation again....more

title: The Poisonwood Bible
author: Kingsolver, Barbara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm 20+ years late to the party, but I am happy to have gotten over my prejudice and to have finally read this masterpiece. Poisonwood Bible is the 3rI'm 20+ years late to the party, but I am happy to have gotten over my prejudice and to have finally read this masterpiece. Poisonwood Bible is the 3rd novel by Kingsolver that I read in the last four months. The only advantage to having discovered her writing later is that I still have her back catalogue to indulge in. I plan to.There are over 700,000 s and ratings of this novel on GR, it's astounding that it's got a rating over 4 stars, most literary fiction books tend to be an overall rating under 4 stars. Yes, I'm in awe of Kingsolver, she's one super intelligent woman, and on top of that, she's got an immense talent for writing. This novel can be analysed to death, there's so much to admire, dissect and learn. At its centre, we have the Prices, made up of the patriarch, the Baptist preacher, Nathan Price, his wife, Leah and their four daughters, Orleanna, Adah, Rachel and Ruth May. As was the case back in the day, and I'm sure it's still the case for some, when the man decided he was going somewhere and his family had to go with him, there was no considering the other people's wishes and hopes. So the Prices find themselves removed from their way of life in Georgia, USA, to some village in the middle of nowhere Congo, with no running water, no electricity, no comforts whatsoever. The learning curve was huge. The wife and the girls, by way of their personalities, and roles adapted to their environment, while the patriarch stayed the same, his only focus was to convert those lost souls (insert rolling of eyes). I mean the women did all the exhausting work, back-breaking work, so the man had the time to ponder about one's soul and god when he was provided with what he needed to survive. Did I know much about Congo? Not really. So learning more about that region was greatly appreciated. Colonialism, post-colonialism, self-determinism, and religious colonialism are some of the big themes, explored mostly via personal histories, which is how people experience history.Another big part of the novel is, especially in the first half, the lack of autonomy and self-determination that women and children experienced, some still do, I'm sure. Oh, how I hated the patriarch of the family, I couldn't care less that he might have had trauma from the war, his obsession/religiousness, the abuse of the wife and his daughters and the lack of self-reflection, gave me no cause to stop hating him. I would have to investigate why Kingsolver chose not to have him express his POV. I'm sure it's a good reason. :-) It didn't go unnoticed how the women became their own resolute and accomplished selves, once they escaped the shackles of religion and men.I'll need to re-read this in print. The audiobook was well narrated by Dean Robertson, but I would have preferred to have had different narrators for each character. Now I need to see what amazing titles beat this stupendous novel to the many awards it was nominated for....more

There wasn't much of a plot, and the little plot there was, it felt constrictive and unimaginative. And I didn't see any redeeming features in Rule (who also happened to have a stupid name - WTF?). And Shaw - she was ... I don't know... kind of boring? "Poor" her, her parents didn't pay attention to her... and the ex was absolutely obsessed with her (this felt like such a forced dramatic addition). And I'm really getting tired of the virgin who's better than anyone else, not to mention, that they all have amazing first time sex, and multiple orgasms (that's when you know you're reading fiction ;-)) and the fact that all the other women the duchebag Rule sleeps with are called whores, chicks etc. And it pisses me off even more when a woman/girl calls other women that. Just saying. Anyway, I only read 85%, I couldn't be bothered finishing it, as I knew how it was going to end. ...more

title: Lolita
author: Nabokov, Vladimir
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I first read Lolita twenty-one years ago. It was a serendipitous find. I was in a bookshop looking at books, taking shelter from the rain. I spotted aI first read Lolita twenty-one years ago. It was a serendipitous find. I was in a bookshop looking at books, taking shelter from the rain. I spotted a table with heavily discounted books. I saw Lolita, saw it was written by a Russian, but most importantly, it cost the exact amount of cash I had in my purse, so I bought it. I started reading it and I was instantly mesmerised. Talking to a friend of mine about books, I told him I was reading this most disturbing book that was so well written, I couldn't stop reading. When I mentioned the name, he was surprised I hadn't heard of the book or the author before. It was the first time I read a book that made me feel extremely uncomfortable, where the characters were so utterly vile and despicable. The voice was like nothing I'd read before. It truly blew my mind away. Ah, I forgot to mention it was a translation.So, I was curious to find out if the novel will be as affecting two decades later, as a less naive woman, with more life experience, and a mother of a twelve-year-old girl. Most importantly, this time it was the original English version. Having Jeremy Irons read it to me was quite the treat.I won't lie, it took some work to separate myself as a young girl, my own daughter and Humbert Humbert from every male individual. The leering, the lusting, the manipulations, were difficult to absorb without vomiting. As time progressed, I got lured in by Humbert's musings. He's the suavest, the most enthralling wordsmith you'll encounter in literature. And he's pleading his case to you, the reader, and he makes you pay attention. His language is of the highest level, his analogies, metaphors, similes and wonderful wordplays trap you in. You might as well give in and ride along the libidinous, lascivious, sick Humbert Humbert. Oh, I can only imagine the outrage of the puritanical Americans. How gutsy were Nabokov and the publishers? I need to read more about its history and some interviews with Nabokov (I tried to watch the interviews on YouTube but I couldn't stand Nabokov's voice, so I'd rather read). Of course, I need to read more Nabokov. Lolita will keep its place on my My favourite books of all time/Masterpieces  shelf.Suddenly, I have a hankering to watch the movie, the Jeremy Irons version. ...more

title: Beautiful Bastard        (Beautiful Bastard, #1)
author: Lauren, Christina*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Hmm, can you give a book a Minus Star? Ok, so here's the deal: I was in the mood for something light, non-challenging, romantic etc. So I went to GoodHmm, can you give a book a Minus Star? Ok, so here's the deal: I was in the mood for something light, non-challenging, romantic etc. So I went to Goodreads and found some lists. BB was rated highly so I downloaded it. I didn't expect a literary masterpiece, but even I could write better, much better, and I'm crap at writing and have no imagination, but apparently nor did Christina Lauren ,(I sure hope this is a pen name, as I would not dare ever publish such a piece of garbage). I just Googled the name. So, it's not just one "brilliant" writer but two.WOW! OMFG! I read a few s before I started writing mine. I had no idea what P2P was, nor fan fiction, so I had to look it up. Given the amount of books available, to think that women would waste their time with this piece of garbage, to think that some of you would rate this over 2 stars - it's absolutely incomprehensible. That trees had to die to have this thing printed is unfathomable.Apparently, this book had a publisher, which supposedly means an editor. Somebody who can read and write has edited this book? What a joke!!!!I could only read about 8% on my Kindle, as I just couldn't continue. I wanted a book to relax me, not to irritate the hell out of me. There was nothing remotely sexy or erotic. The dialogues made me twitch! The character development - non-existent. The first person narration is annoying as hell, but to have that back and forth between the two idiot protagonists is even more annoying. The dude is referring to the woman as a bitch when he's thinking about her? Really? That doesn't do it for me. Nor does cum swallowing. Yuck!!! I thought that was supposed to be written for women, unless the two "brilliant" authors watched too much porn - which is made for men - and got confused about what women like/want (yeah, I know, there are exceptions). Ah, and every single time there's an amorous encounter between the two fucktards, there's panty ripping involved. So much passion! (insert sarcasm). There's no time for removing one's underwear. But the thing that was the "sexiest" is that the male fucktard keeps the ripped underwear in a drawer. I'll stop, as really, it's not worth wasting any more time. Obviously, I shall refrain from looking at Goodreads as a source of suggestions, even when it comes to trashy "literature". There was not one redeemable thing about this novel. Oh, I'm sorry, I'm being dishonest: the cover is not bad. ...more
